Honestly a bit of a disappointment compared to the first one, and feels like it could have just been dlc for the first. Everywhere you go feels the same and there just isn't anything to really do once you've got one of every slime. Where as the first one had a lot to do in the late game, the late game is non existent here. Once you've unlocked the other two parts of the map, you've seen most of what the game loop will be. Even then the map is just boring an repetitive, the first one had so many biomes but here its "grassy plane" and "Volcano", with volcano being a super short segment. Once all the gordo's have been popped you've won the game, something that can realistically take you 4-5 hours if you've played the first. Everything new is just mediocre at best. Theres a weather mechanic but it just feels a bit lifeless? Like yea theres a tornado but it doesn't do anything besides move things up a few feet then set it gently back down. The new upgrade system just removed some of the randomness in getting materials in favor of making you wait forever. All the new slimes could have easily been added to the old game as DLC, they don't even add new mechanics. Two just fly around and that it, and the other is a pink slime thats yellow. 

Just play the first game until this one is finished (if ever)

I played the first Slime Rancher as a refresher before this one came out. The slimes were still slimy and the map still felt like home. 

I got Slime Rancher 2 a few minutes after it came out and played it the same day. I have always been navigationally impaired but it seems Rainbow Island has a more convoluted and confusing layout than the Far, Far Range in the first installment. When stepping out of the ranch area it feels like stepping out into the wilderniss, every journey feels like an adventure on Rainbow Island. 

The slimes are slimier and seem stickier than before. The cat-inspired slimes jump at you more often and tarr-outbreaks seem more common. The system for gathering resources now actually demands you explore, rather than build a tiny workbase in every area. The new slimes are adorable and I hope to see many more species added over the course of development. Seeing some of the old ones return is also great, though I'll miss the ones left behind on the Far, Far Range.

As for the downsides...
-  Rainbow Island is brighter and more colorful than the ranch in the first installment which tends to give me a headache, though fiddling with the settings of the game helps mitigate this effect. 

I am extremely excited to see where the rest of the game leads.

I'll add to this review as I gain more hours (currently at 3.5hrs) but so far I have some grievances. Hopefully I'll have some better things to say.

- No mini-map, which I feel this game desperately needs. For some reason, the maps are way harder to navigate than the first game. Maybe I'm just not used to it yet, but after three hours I feel like I should have a better, or even general grasp of where I am in the first area.
- Distance between plots, and especially the refiner, is starting to feel ridiculous. Maybe an increase in movement speed would help. Like come on, this is just annoying.
- Can't store the same items in different tanks. Why is this still a thing? This would definitely help with the distancing issue as well. I don't want to keep running back and forth when I have 100 plorts in the collector, dude.

AMAZING game, while many people may think of it as just a sequel of the previous game, and while it quite IS that right now, this game has so much potential, really hope the devs don't mess it up. First of all, the graphics are incredible, I just kept staring at the sun when I first loaded into my world, everything has such a simple yet satisfying design. Second of all, the music and sfx in general are soo good! Usually I need my spotify open at all times when I play a new game but this one has such beautiful music I just want to listen to it over and over and over again! Everything is amazing, including the "story"! Even as a non-story game it still has some references to the story from the previous game and hopefully will continue it in future updates! Anyway, I'm gonna be rating some aspects of it out of 10 so you can know if it's what you're looking for:
Graphics: 10/10
Audio: 10/10
Price: 9/10
Story: 8/10

Overall: 9.5/10

In conclusion. if you have the money, definitely buy this game, as it is worth every cent! And if you don't, the game does go on sale once every few months, so you can get it when it's price is reduced!

[h1]Slime Rancher 2 Review[/h1]

[strike]I prefer to write in English so that everyone can understand.[/strike]

[b]This game is perfect.[/b]
_________________________

No, I mean really. I was super happy when I received the second part. After I finished the first part, the announcement for the second part appeared.

Part 2 with cuteness. Cute things that help you relax, forget about everyday life and just enjoy without someone yelling in your ear how bad you are even though you did your best. (Online games)

It's still in Early Access BUT you don't really notice that it is. For early access, it already feels like a finished game.

I would even nominate SR2 for "Best Game of the Year" or the "Best Game with Love"... but that's already covered with the first part.

I had already completely finished SR2 in the first week because it quickly becomes addictive. In a good sense of course.

It has a similar structure to SL1 but is a bit different. Of course I'm missing things from first part to second part, but maybe it will come in an update in the future. Who knows.

With new Update with Weather give this game more love and spirit. It's really enjoyable to play.
_________________________

[u]Conclusion:[/u]

The game is ideal if you don't want to have any stress, if you want to calm down or if you want to forget everyday life. And best of all, be a little away from toxic online players and only enjoy with cuteness.
The game is both as well as the first part; a game for every age group. Whether young or old; it is for everyone. It is also for every gender. So guys; you don't have to be ashamed to play something cute. It will do you good. ;)

[h3] Slight spoilers up ahead, I guess? [/h3]


[i]Slime rancher 2[/i] follows off of right after last game, you, the player are tasked to figure out the technology and unknown resources of this island

I lived and breathed the last game (Slime rancher/SR) and I live for SR2 also! 
The game from the start to now has fixed most of its bugs, and added a ton of new things. Yes I know the game is EA (Early access) right now but from the way it was looking before to now... it is a huge upgrade.

For a game which I assume isn't close to being done, [b]the story[/b] we do have is pretty good so far! 
[spoiler]You get a note at the start telling you to come over to Rainbow Island and without a second thought you go to this island not knowing what awaits you! Someone clearly has been there before, and through the drone notes this person left behind, it seems they worked for 7C crop. [/spoiler]
There are some drone notes that are kind of sad but thats best up to you to find them (if you get the game) 
Anyway, like I said, we don't have much on story but I do hope we get a new character to interact with or at least be able to see one of the characters standing in front of us later down the track; It's a lot to ask for but i do hope to see it!
being able to get more messages from Casey too would be wonderful! I know the whole story but I would love to see us (the player) and Casey start to talk again.

[b]The game[/b] is a huge vibe jump from the last game but still manages to capture the same amount of calmness it had in SR, I'm really happy to see that they went with a more rainbow design than another sand/rock theme.

[b]The scenery[/b] is beautiful, even though there a tons of different colours, none of them getting muddy up be each other and in fact most of the time compliment each other!
The habitat for the slime has improved a lot from the last game, both games divided the slimes into their own areas but SR2 improves on this design.
I know the game is in EA but I really do hate the fact that even though you can access Powdefalls Bluffs, you can't do much there but grab some saber slimes and throw some snow around.
On the upside, I am for one loving the map update, they moved some of the islands around so it looks less crowded though it is more on the empty side now but I can't really complain.

Most of [b][the slimes[/b] from the last game are in SR2 now, not much a change in designs but that part is made up for when with the new slimes in the game, even though we only get 5 new slimes they are still amazing in of itself.

[b]The soundtrack[/b] is amazing and really does match the whole game, the music that plays for each island is beautiful and the music that plays when you're near a tar slime or a feral slime is exactly what I imagine fear sounding like in a happy game.

They updated [b]the UI[/b] for the Slimepedia even though the old one was quite fine and reflected SR's UI quite a bit but either way the new is a lot more cleaner looking and it does bounce! (Though i get a headache quick from it)

[b][i]Game settings[/b] are still slow to change, at this point just changed it to a slider, it's a lot faster and I get to control the exact speed/sound/etc I want it to be, it still does it job so complaining would be a waste of time, on the upside you can increase the enemies damage now! You can't really increase it too high but it's still a really good thing to have for people who are looking for a not so hard challenge.

[b]The game controls[/b] are also basic and the same from the last game so nothing to complain on that!

By far the best sequel that Monomi Park could've made for the first Slime Rancher! It's still in development, but for the several hours I have played through this I can see some great potential of this game. The new slimes, new food sources and new graphics are a major improvement from the first Slime Rancher and the new weather especially makes this game a lot different from the first. Just the overall feel of the game and the improved graphics makes it a lot more of a cosy and casual experience from the first one. I'd highly recommend this game to people who like casual farming/managing/exploring games and love cute creatures.

So far I am LOVING this game! The new slimes are so cute and I do like the new resource collection system! The graphics upgrade is honestly awesome! The game is so beautiful! My current only issues are the amount of tarrs and, in general, the amount of wild plorts that just kinda happen, and the spawn rate of resources. Radiant Ore has been such a struggle for me and a few friends of mine, but so far this is amazing! I'm so excited to see how far this game will go!

Update:
After this most recent update I'm still absolutely loving Slime Rancher 2. The new slimes are great and I'm happy to see old one's return. Finding resources Isn't much of an issue at all anymore, however the wild plort and slime spawning is still wild. I play with tars off simply because I can't handle the sheer amount of them in a game that I play to relax in. The weather system is great and honestly beautiful!  Other than the wild slime and plort spawning, I don't really have any issue with the game!

While Slime Rancher 2 retains the charm of its predecessor, I find it challenging to wholeheartedly recommend it in its current state. The game seems to lack substantial new content, with the only new additions that extend the duration of mundane tasks rather than introducing fresh and engaging experiences. If you're content with a reskin of the first game and enjoy its familiar elements, then Slime Rancher 2 is for sure a fitting choice for you. However, personally, I had hoped for a sequel that would bring about significant changes and innovative gameplay I found lacking in this current state.
I love this game still to this day! I see it at a must buy to listen to the sound track and now rain! So calming and the slimes are always super cute, pouty, angry, or just giggling!

Okay so as I am playing the early acces I'll update my review with every update until the final release (and if they do any DLCs) except for bugfixes and things like that:

Song of the Sabers: The snow physics and the northern ligths are absoluteley beautiful and very well optimised, I thought my pc wasn't gonna be able to run it but it does and very smoothly, I don't like that they demistified the saber slimes but they are cute, and the yolky slime is so hard to find and so weird that I thought it was a hoax but its real and cute xD

Come Rain or Slime: OMG the wather system is sooo cool and feels so natural, Thunderstorms are epic, rain is relaxing, pollen is beautiful and slimefall, lol thats just terraria's slime rain, I love it, There are no new areas that I have found, the 'new' slimes apear with weahter and the painted chickens apear randomly I think
But again, abosutely beautiful and very very well optimised.

🙂My 𝙋𝙚𝙧𝙨𝙤𝙣𝙖𝙡 Opinion🙃

BEAUTIFUL! this game is huge, definiteley worth the price, I do hope stickers, trading cards and achievements will be added which thy surely will, I love the new graphics, the new relaxing music, the new kinds of slime, this game is just fantastic, the cutest game on the planet, and not preciseley Earth.
Even in early acces It's really well optimised and polished, I haven't found any major bugs and have no complaints
Monomy Park is a really caring company for their game and community so they probably will update this game for years to come, so pretty cool and worthit; So if you're still deciding if you should buy this game, please Do, and if you haven't played the first game you can still play this one but you should go play that one too :b

🚧 Early Acces Sugestions 🚧

The graphics, music and gameplay are absoluteley great but I have some sugestions for future updates
- Have a mini map, Only in areas where the map is unlocked but it would be super helpful for navigating this bigger world
- Map markers, If we have a map we should also be able to mark points of interest, again only in unlocked areas 
- Steam Items: Trading cards, Point-Shop items, achievements and all that stuff, I know they are probably working on it already but I had to put it here anyways :b

That's all xd, the game is actually pretty polished and of course I hope for new expansions and stuff but that's all I ask, thanks for reading :)

Decent but feels sparse compared to the first game. There are not enough upgrades or ingame rewards to warrant farming at all - you quickly surpass the amount of money you need for basic upgrades making plort farming a waste of time. Areas are locked behind specific resources that don't always spawn (currently writing this while waiting for my fourth night cycle in a row waiting for a nighttime-only fruit to spawn). The most annoying thing for me is how spread out the base is. This was something I really expected them to improve on after the first game but instead the base feels even more labyrinthine and spread out than it did in the first game. There is a two-way teleporter available but it isn't unlocked until the end of the current content and farming the materials for it is tedious (more world resource drops).

Game is still in early access after 14 months. Not much has changed in that time and the updates have been focused around adding minor content (adding slimes that already existed in the first game...) rather than fixing core issues with the gameplay loop. I hesitate to recommend it right now and would say you would be better off replaying the first one. There is really nothing about this game that the first one didn't do better.

if you wanted more slime rancher 1, make sure to buy a better pc or you'll end up with the most shitty graphics imagineable.
it really is laughable. the graphics in slime rancher 1 always gave me hundreds of fps and looked better than the graphics in this game that causes my pc to overheat and have 30 fps at max, WHILE still locking biomes and worlds behind teleporters and loading screens, which is what the original barely did and still managed to optimise it better.

the majority of the content like slimes and foods are straight up ripped from the original game and the map is also very confusing to navigate, which is to be expected, but it seems very intentional or intentionally difficult to learn in this case

the game is awfully grindy. i always wanted a bit more grindy slime rancher because for an example the major upgrades to your player character could have been all unlocked with really little coins in the original game.
well, they might've done them too grindy.
upgrades cost a fair more amount of coins while costing materials like deep brine from the original game.
you also need to find treasure pods that unlock the blueprint for said upgrade, which means that you very well could never find the treasure pod that gives you the energy meter upgrade lvl 2 or the jetpack upgrade.
every trip that you take to get the materials for an upgrade take up to 30 minutes and you could very well still not get enough materials, which is very grindy.

at least they made the plort market and the material system much more interesting.
the plort market actually works like a stock market now. when you sell, it goes down, but if you keep your plorts, it goes up and you sell for more.
materials also do not need to be mined by auto miners just like in the original game anymore, you just have to use your vac pack to suck them up from material deposits around the map.

the game is pretty fun at first and i was really hyped but the blatant flaws quickly became obvious and just made me want to stop playing, so i could wait for the full release and have fun playing the game in its released state

also make sure to buy it after early access because it is not worth buying in it's current state.

I cannot recommend this game at present. In its current condition, it feels like a half done dlc. I may change my review in the future, but at present the content available does not warrant this being a sequel that is 50% more expensive than the first game. At the time of review, come rain or slime has been released, and the game lacks the charm of the first. Resource collection is mind numbing as you run around the map like a headless chicken as you desperately search for the resources you need to upgrade your gear, only to realize you need to also constantly hope you find the correct blueprint for the upgrades, and not another decoration. At present, money serves almost no purpose as you can rapidly get enough to buy all the ranch expansions available. It is also frustrating that despite playing as Beatrix, we dont have all the gear from the first game and don't really get much reason as to why. We get minimal content with the characters from the first game. The map is a nightmare to navigate due to its lack of strongly distinct islands. The first three islands share several biomes and it all blends together. The drive to explore is just not there as the rewards are always another decoration and not a hyper rare slime only in one spot, or a mystery or new form of puzzle to solve. The gameplay is extremely similar to the first with the plort puzzles put everywhere. If you are a veteran from the first game, it will feel tedious after a couple hours as it turns into a glorified collectithon. The devs know all this as well, the game opens with a disclaimer that it is a work in progress, but it is a work in progress that offers a fraction of the content as the first game, while missing most of the first games features, such as automation and interesting puzzles, as well as an interesting story. It feels tedious. I cannot help but feel that Monomi Park is somehow in dire financial straights as the fact that they charge $30 for this game while the first is $20 despite this barely feeling like anything more than a dlc that strips everything you had from the basegame. That said, feels like they buffed coops so, 10/10

I love Slime Rancher 1, and I anticipate loving this game, but I would really recommend waiting until it fully releases. This review will go into detail for every update, what they added and why they improved on this fantastic game, as well as giving them all a 1-5 star review

Early-access release:
The main thing that Slime rancher 2 changes from the prequel is the complete rework of the gadget and resource system. In the original, the refinery was not available until you reached a pretty high level. To the point where you would most likely have completed the main story by the time you unlock it. All of the resources you use to refine stuff are ecxtracted using drills. Now, you get access to the refinery immediatly at the start and resources just spawn in the world around you. This version also reworked the upgrades, in the prequel they all just costed money and as such could all be obtained way too easily. Now upgrades are made in the refinery from resources and money, making them harder to obtain but still reasonable. Other than that slime rancher 2 features 3 new areas not in slime rancher 1, 5 new slimes and the return of 12 slimes from the original. Very good 8/10

Song of the Sabers:
This update features a new area, new secret slime and the return of the Saber slime from the first game. In this game, you can actally encounter un-largo'd sabers and their favorite food is revealed. The amount of new and exciting things this update offers is astounding for the first update in an early access game. I love it. I honestly can't find anything to complain about. 10/10

Come rain or slime:
This update adds a weather system to the game, i never thought that this change could make the world feel so much more dynamic and interesting. This update also re-adds the dervish and tangle slime from the first game as well as their favorite food. Both of these slime spawn anywhere as long as a specific weather is there, this wasn't how they worked in slime rancher 1 and i think this makes them more interesting. Walking through the starlight strand for hunter plort when all of a sudden vines cover the walls and floor and these adorable little guys pop out! It's fantastic. I do have a complaint with this update though, that is that it didn't add anything to do. Like yeah you can collect the tangle and dervish slimes to add them to the slimepedia and if you want make a corral for them in the conservatory. But there's no new upgrades to buy, no new gadgets, areas, treasure pods, achievements, or anything. Not to say this update was too small it is a totally acceptable size for an update, but there's nothing to accomplish if you've already completed the previous updates which not everyone has done but i'm sure alot of hardcore fans have. Anyho, this game is amazing and i love it so much.  7/10

Overall this game is a 9/10

There's a large world here to explore but all you can hope to get from all this exploring, is a new type of tree for you to spawn somewhere else in the world. Game isn't as fun as the original and I despise Rainbow Fields, but sure is pretty.

Why do I hate Rainbow Fields, you ask? Well, it's more so a problem that there is no HUD compass to tell you what direction you're facing. There's like 4 portals leading to the areas in RF because it's the hub area where your conservatory is, obviously, but since I can't tell what direction I'm facing and RF is very vertical, I constantly get lost and find the wrong portal or can't even find my ranch because I keep getting turned around and can't tell what direction I'm facing in. Might not be a problem for everyone, but I can't tell you how many times I've gone in loopty-loops trying to find the damn conservatory.

And in general, I know it's an early access game like the original was, but I'm finding the micro-managing of this game to be way more tedious and annoying than the original, which I'm not sure why. The ranch area is slightly bigger, yes, but since this version of EA doesn't have drones yet and minimal teleporters, I had my entire ranch's plort collectors overloaded because I just couldn't be bothered spending an entire game day cleaning them when I could be resource gathering. Unlike the first game where I clean up a bit and feel comfortable leaving the ranch for a day or two and be able to handle the plorts, here I'm constantly worrying about all the crap I have to do when I get back instead of enjoying the environments and the graphics. I'm not sure what's different to cause this shift in managing priorities as I said, but somehow this game is more stressful than the original for me despite being nearly identical.

Overall, it's fine. If you enjoyed Slime Rancher then yes, you will enjoy this one as well. Very similar elements to the first one but with some differences too. Getting the Jetpack is a little bit more difficult than the first but it will unlock more areas or make areas easier to traverse. All the new slimes are adorable and some have a fun little gimmick. I know I'm definitely enjoying myself while playing and I'm looking forward to any updates the game will get in the future. There is so much room for more slimes to be added. 

I've noticed while I play that the screen once in a while flicker to black and at first, I thought that it was my TV that was the problem, but I recently got new monitors for my computer and it still did that. It was the game itself and I don't know why it flashed to black for a split second but it was only once and not for a while. The jumping in the game is a little unpredictable and can cause you to fall into the slime sea or miss where you want to land. This is amplified a bit when you get the Jetpack but you have a bit to catch yourself and save yourself from jumping into the slime sea provided that you have enough energy to get back.

Edit 11/13/23: The Flashing black thing is fixed. I haven't seen that since but the jumping is still a little sensitive. I'm finding that I jump farther than I mean to even without the jetpack still and it just gives me little moments of panic where I think I'm about to land in the slime sea.

Im editing this from a positive to a negative, dont get this game. Just get the first one.

Its fun within the first, 6 hours of gameplay. But after that its repetitive, boring, lame, and overall way to tedious to want to keep playing. If I wanted to subjugate myself to a 2 hour long process of something, I would go make macaroons. I dont. I wanted to play this game and feel like I accomplished something within 30-40 minutes..maybe an hour tops. 

Instead, I spend 2 hours: 
Collecting food that isnt already dead, from my reset 4 times farm because it grows to fast, and I cant automate it.
Shove what I cant fit (which is only 30 at the moment) into storage.
Run roughly 5-10 minutes, to each slime area (sometimes more than once to each) feeding slimes, and collecting excess plorts.
Spend another, 5-10 minutes selling it, sometimes longer. 
Run around outside the farm trying to complete the Gordos (I dont remember, the really giant slimes you feed alot of food too, which...i would have....if it wasnt dead, ya know) 99% of the time, not even having THAT food item, so hopefully finding resources and swapping them for rarer and rarer ones.......

Only to run back. Realize I didnt need those resources. And another 2-3 batches of crops are dead, with all my slime plorts being overfilled and way to much food in the slime pens. Regretting every decision even getting this game. 

Then rage quitting and playing  Dinkum. 

So yeah. Do not buy this game, unless you like repeating the same grueling task over, and over, and over, and over, and over........with sprinkles of hopes that you remember the true resources you need, while crossing your fingers they re-spawned. 

Thats about it. Its a cashgrab I wish I could refund and get my money back. I never regretted buying a game so much as this one....

Not enough content to peak my interest for nearly long enough to justify the $30 price tag. Luckily I got it on sale, but as far as I can tell, those are few and far between. They haven't implemented automation gadgets either so you have to manually mine everything the slow way. It doesn't help that it's the Exact. Same. Gameplay loop. Give this game a few years and it will be fun, but it does very little to branch out or be unique in my opinion. The visuals are nice, but the ranching is almost identical in the end. All the same farming strategies, synergies, etc. Upgrades are also the same. Vac upgrades it tried to branch out for, but in a really annoying way. It forces you to look around for really rare materials and I just end up doing laps around the same spawnzones over and over for them.

So, yeah. If you want your slime rancher fix REALLY bad, go ahead and get this game. Otherwise, put them back in the oven for another year or two.

slime.

Slime Rancher 2 is pure relaxation! Managing cute slimes and exploring the colorful world is an absolute joy. The charming graphics, soothing gameplay, and lovable slimes make it the perfect game to unwind and enjoy. Highly recommended for a stress-free gaming experience.

I may change my recommendation at a later time, but right now I can't recommend this title at this price point. There's not enough content, there aren't enough updates. I did not play Slime Rancher 1 so I can't even join the chorus of "this is the same, but reskinned" that I'm seeing.

There's no plot. No quests. Just pick up slimes and put them in your ranch. It doesn't take long at all to max out on slimes and lose any interest in exploration except to gather the items that you can't ranch, and that's just to build decorations that are very limited in where they can be placed.

Maybe once this goes out of early access it will have enough added to be worth the money, but now that I'm 20 hours in and very thoroughly reached the limit of what can be done, I feel robbed.

TL;DR: Fun for a while, until you realize its a grind fest with a lack of content beyond base Slime Rancher. Wait for the full release or buy Slime Rancher 1.

This game has a much different upgrade system than Slime Rancher 1 which in theory is an improvement, but in execution leaves fatal flaws that are very easily noticed. Much like the gadgets in slime rancher 1, the upgrades are crafted using materials and plorts. However, materials are locked behind timed resource deposits, resetting every 1-2 days, with some spawns not even being guaranteed. In order to go get these materials, you'll need to venture far across the islands and hope and pray they decided to spawn that day. While you're gone, your slimes will produce endless plorts, too many for one person to handle. When you eventually come home to deposit/use your materials, you'll find that there are way too many plorts to deal with. it will usually take 30 minutes to an hour to clear your ranch of excess plorts. While this may sound like a good thing, there is absolutely nothing to spend your money on. No 7Zee rewards, No toys, and the decorations available are way lamer than Slime Rancher 1, just being trees and rocks you would find on other islands. In addition to money being near useless if you aren't literally within the first 3 hours of your save, there are ZERO methods of automation for anything found in game. No automation for plort collection, sale, or storage. No automation for resource gathering or storage. Ultimately, this leads to the main gameplay loop being: Leave to gather materials > Come home > Spend 30 minutes to an hour cleaning up plorts and feeding slimes > Rinse and repeat. You may be asking yourself why I haven't mentioned any of the mini-games or quests found in Slime Rancher 1. That's because they aren't here. The only impact the NPCs from Slime Rancher 1 have on this game is occasionally calling you and giving you a blueprint or a lame decoration. For this game being over a year into it's early access, it feels like abandonware, the game feeling like a shell of Slime Rancher 1. DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. If you already own Slime Rancher 1, play that. If you don't, buy that instead. Wait for this game to fully release to buy it, and even then, be cautious and read up to see if the lack of content has been fixed.

I'm disappointed to see that this game is mostly made of reused stuff from the first Slime Rancher. Some things were not added such as minigames, and for example the deluxe coop upgrade is just there from the start without the need to unlock it, however, there are no new upgrades to the base buildings, there are no new models, these are all taken 1:1 from the first game and put here, so it really looks like it's copy paste game.
The game also is not as smooth as the first was, there are minor stutters every minute or so, and that was when playing on medium settings. I had no issues on the highest settings in the first game.

Alright so there are of course more slime types, and while cute and fun to play with, nothing has changed when it comes to how the old ones look or sound, nothing has also changed in terms of how you manage your base, as mentioned before there are no new features or items, for the almost 3 hours I've spent I have seen only a single new veggie, brace yourselves for regular or stony hens, pogofruits, carrots and cuberries for at least few first hours of the game.
Market is exactly the same as it was.
Refinery and fabricator are there from the start and you now use them to upgrade your vacpack, the previous upgrades that were purchased with just Newbucks require Plorts and special items such as Brine. It limits how quickly you upgrade everything, and in my opinion is a bit more elegant than the previous "wait for something to unlock next upgrade and just buy it because you're already stacked on Newbucks".
The drills, pumps and apiaries are not there anymore, instead the resources such as Deep Brine are collected outside your ranch with your vac after you purchase a Resource Harvester upgrade, these resources are now special nodes that contain 2 or 3 items, and then are put on a timer and you need to return for more later.
Treasure pods can be opened without any upgrades, and they contain decorations or blueprints.
Tarrs are just as scary and dangerous as they were previously. Meaning they can be ignored.

The biggest sin for me was that there don't seem to be any return teleports in the world or available by feeding Gordos like there were in the first game, at least there were no teleports under 4 Gordos, which is a bummer and requires you to either fabricate a one-way teleporter or run back to the base. It's really tedious.
The biomes are no longer connected by land, but they have teleporters that are turned on with the same buttons as there were in Ancient City found behind gordos or "insert X type plort into a statue" puzzle, oh and there is also a loading screen whenever you travel from one biome to the other, it's rather annoying after not having to deal with loading screens in the first game.

Overall I would rate the game "Slime Rancher 1, but less".

So far, I am loving this game just as much as the first one. When deciding to buy this game, keep in mind that it is in early access still and probably will continue to be for a while. Many features, including but not limited to, automation, story, and progression is, at this point, very incomplete or entirely non-existent. So don't expect a full game at this juncture. Despite this, I can see the future of this game is looking very bright, maybe even surpassing that of the first game.

For the sake of clarity, I have sensory sensitivity. Which essentially means that certain sensory stimulus can make me physically ill and mentally exhausted, where most other people would be just fine. This game knocked me out of commission for 5 hours in total today, due to how bad it made me feel. Admittedly I did push my limits a little, and I should not have tried to play a second time later. But I wanted to be sure that I tried to see if changing settings would make it easier to play or not. It did not. 

I don't know for sure why its making me so unwell, but I do have two theories;
1. It's so incredibly bright, all the colours are bright and there is bright lights everywhere. There are no dark colours to even it out, and there are too many bright light sources in the game.
2. There is no depth in the game, its a 3D game so I am honestly lost on how that happened. Maybe its the lack of good shadows? idk

TLDR; The game in its current iteration is not friendly to neurodivergent folk that cant handle bright lights and colours, and is unplayable for me. Therefore I can not recommend this game, even if I know I would love it if i would not have these issues.

As the game is currently, it still has that lovely Slime Rancher charm to it. Going from Slime Rancher 1 to Slime Rancher 2 feels like a seamless transition. The polish is amazing, despite it being in EA. I haven't encountered any bugs or glitches so far, even though I'm on Linux. The graphics are beautiful! The music is very enjoyable. There is a lot to explore and discover! The new slimes are adorable. Resource hunting is more enjoyable now that we can use the vac to gather items. It's definitely worth the full price tag even in EA. I got over 20 hours in my first run and still didn't explore or find everything. If you enjoyed the mechanics and vibes of the first game and want more, then you'll like this one too. I definitely look forward to this game's development and completion!

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW: 

This is basically the same game as the first slime rancher - and I wanted more of that, so I bought this and I'm having fun. The same amount of fun I had playing the first slime rancher. 

The ONLY priority they should have for this game, to make it an obvious choice over the first game, is MULTIPLAYER. If they aren't planning on adding Multiplayer, I think Slime Rancher 2 was kind of a waste of time, and should have just been a Slime Rancher expansion. 

It's EXPENSIVE for being basically a new map with some new slimes. The biggest noticeable improvement for me so far is the graphics. However, when I look at the first game vs this one, it's like everything is shrouded in fog. Not really sure why, I got used to it though. 

I do love the (eventual) idea of having funny toys and rides for your slimes, and having different ways to interact with them and the world. I'm excited to have more options to decorate my ranch and islands. However, none of that is actually released as of this review.

So, if you're new to Slime Rancher, you might as well enjoy the first one.
There's no plans for multiplayer on Slime Rancher 2 anyway, and currently it's the exact same game. 

UPDATE OCT 2023: early access took me about 15 hours of very relaxed game play to explore and unlock everything. 

I feel like there is A LOT more work that needs to be done to be comparable to the first game, nevermind better. 

The last gordo slime, the one sitting in front of a rainbow to somewhere - had nothing to do with the rainbow. The rainbow is a place holder for something cool later. Of course I only found out after collecting the rare food it eats over several days. I was very disappointed. 

Not anticipating this being out of early access for a while considering the above.

I absolutely love Slime Rancher as a franchise. This is my comfort game, and has been since I first got it on my Xbox One nearly 5 years ago. This game is no different- though to a lesser extent. Most of the gripes I have about this game purely come from the fact that it's still in early access though. The game has crashed my computer not once, but twice now, the most recent completely rendering both my monitor outputs useless until I restarted my computer. It doesn't have a ton of content right now, but it's to be expected.

The bugs and game-breaking glitches, I trust, will be fixed in time. I'm happy to be patient for Monomi Park, because god, do I respect them as a dev team. I really just hope this ends up living up to its predecessor's name when it leaves early access. I'd still recommend buying this game, if only just to support a top-tier developer.

I bought Slime Rancher 1 for my birthday when it came out those years ago. It was so much fun; I remember stopping after I automated every plot and had bees running my entire farm. This year, I bought Slime Rancher 2 for my birthday in 2023, a year after it was released. I had fun for the first few hours, it got a little bit repetitive hours 6-8, and now, at hour 10 (38 days), I have "beat" the game after unlocking all the slimes currently available and all the tech. There is not nearly as much automation content, and many of the slimes are the same. As much as I loved to play the first game, I would not recommend slime rancher 2 unless its on sale.

If you liked Slime Rancher, you'll like Slime Rancher 2.  The gameplay loop is the same, but with new slime friends and a new, beautiful map to explore.  The ranch itself is a little better designed than in the first game - slightly less running to and fro because the layout is just more efficient.  You have to like a game where most of he experience is running to and fro anyways though to get enjoyment from these titles..  Luckily, I do!  It's very relaxing and cute.  Only thing I hope for sooner rather than later is achievements, though those presumably will not be available until the game is actually finished with development.  It's more polished than the first game which says a lot because the first was already very polished (and this game still isn't finished!).  The characters feel more lively and memorable, and the story I am finding more engaging than that of the first game.

This game is honestly just cute and delightful! The graphics are better than the first game, which was to be expected. The main gameplay is the same as the first game; Wrangle slimes and ranch them, but the way you gather materials for slime science is different; instead of machines just drilling/pumping/... you collect the recourses yourself, which I find to be a fun change. The new location is beautiful, and the conservatory looks stunning. The new slime variants are adorable and the ones that return (or are planned to return) are still the same little goofballs. I also like how you can toggle Tar slimes and feral slimes when creating a new save. The way the story (?) / lore is partially it's own thing, but also expands on the previous game (from what i can tell) is also really nice, since you don't necessarily have to know the previous game's lore/story by heart to understand what's being told. But Most importantly, the tabby largo combinations are still incredibly adorable (I love Honey-Tabby largos :D).

As someone who played the first Slime Rancher to death I have to say that this game does more than disappoint.  The state that the game released in, and has remained in, is unethical.

Pros: There are numerous systems to the original slime rancher that have been significantly improved.  The access to the upgrade system from the start is a great one.  Making all the upgrades materials found in the world or plorts is also a great idea. I genuinely feel rewarded by interacting with the games systems, instead of trying to min/max money.  The world exploration is also significantly improved by making meta progression through caches in the world and making them accessible from the beginning.  It was incredibly frustrating in the first game to find a cache and not be able to open it until I did something arbitrary, and then get a lackluster aesthetic reward. I had a lot of fun going through the world to find all the caches and upgrading my gear using them.

Cons: There is a significant lack of content.  I mean a serious lack of content.  There are major features of the first title that were not and still aren't available in the game a year later.  I excused this when it first went early access as I thought this was just a test for players to react to systems and that content would be sporadically released, however the content release has been extremely slow moving.  I completely finished all the content in the game in only a few hours.  I didn't feel like I was playing a game in early access, I felt like I was playing a test demo.  This game went into early access way too early.  I feel like they promised a date, and instead of admitting that they couldn't keep up with that time table, they just polished the stuff they had and sent it out.  

This game is absolutely not worth the 30 dollars they are charging for it.  Slime rancher 1 is.

If you loved the original Slime Rancher, you're gunna love this one too!
Even though this one is still in Early Access, the amount of content already in it makes it almost feel like a complete game! There is a whole experience to already be had!
The new slimes are adorable, the new sights are breath-taking, and the new, sort of overhaul feeling of coming updates, really makes this game stand out, in my opinion. From the original confines of Slime Rancher, Slime Rancher 2 is breaking through with more player immersion, the upcoming Come Rain or Slime update, it'll not only reintroduce slimes from the first game, but really bring in that touch of "wow, I really feel like I'm there". Truly exciting!
The story so far is theory inducing, I won't spoil it, but it really gets the gears grinding, just like how it did in the first game with Hobson's notes!
The game is just as exciting as the first, the physics are amazing, the feel of this game is definitely the same, yet improved!
I'm absolutely in love with Slime Rancher and Slime Rancher 2, and I'm definitely excited to see how it continues to play out!

A fun and relaxing exploration game. I recommend it, but there are a couple improvements I still think it needs.

Pros:
- Calm and Relaxing
- Visually Appealing Art Style
- Not excessively challenging (simple game, not overly involved).
- It honestly is just a fun soothing game.

Cons:
- No direction from the game. You have access to the slimepedia, but it would be nice if the game explained some mechanics ie finding the rainbow upgrade globe things around the map, how tarr slimes form, how favorite foods work, how to expand areas, using plorts to open certain areas, even just telling the player they can open the slimepedia-- there just is not any instruction given or tutorial beyond the initial control. Even if you upgrade your character to have pulsewave or other abilities it does not even tell you what button activates them unless you check the controls. You really just have to guess and figure things out for yourself.  
- There is not really any objective or milestones. Other than "unlock all the upgrades" or "expand all the areas" or "unlock all the plorts" is just relatively idle. I would like if the game offered missions or had objectives for the player periodically. Ie bring X of these slimes to this NPC (and it gives you an upgrade) or upgrade a slimes corral to have high walls (and it gives you something else) etc.

It's a really fun and cute game, however I have some nitpicks. In the original, you could trade with the other ranchers via the range exchange. In Slime Rancher 2, there is no range exchange or anything like it. In this game, you get some cosmetic/utility stuff from the other ranchers from the first game when they call you. Sometimes they just tell you insane lore stuff, while other times they just tell you "Hey, take this!" and throw some rainbow grass at you. I like the upgrade system and the chip/drive/etc. finding via capsules, because it allows for even more exploration. Tbh I don't really like the lack of an e-mail system like in SR1. I know this game is still in development and there definitely will be lots of stuff added via updates + I haven't finished the main story yet. All in all, I really enjoy this game and I'd recommend it to everyone.

*[b]Note[/b]: Do not let my very low playtime fool you. I've been playing Slime Rancher 2 on and off since the release date on XBGP and finally decided to purchase it on Steam. This review will still be updated when I feel the need, but please keep this in mind.

I suppose another thing to note is I was unbelievably excited for the release of Slime Rancher 2. With the announcement trailer I bawled my eyes out because it's predecessor remains one of the main games I boot up when I need to relax and de-stress. I had to have watched the trailers a million times before we were finally given a release date that took place last year. I don't know why I waited so long to own it here alongside the former but I'm glad to finally add it to my collection. 

If the original Slime Rancher gives the calming feeling of coming home after a long day, then this sequel can only be considered the feeling of cuddling up with a warm blanket and diving into your favorite novel or watching your favorite movie; the feeling of sitting out on your front steps and watching the sunset at the end of the day; the feeling of stargazing with your best friend and dreaming of how big the world truly is. That is how this game feels to me. It is simply the feeling of peace. 

There is nothing to state here that couldn't be said about the former as well. The visuals are gorgeous, the colors are so vivid, the music is absolutely beautiful. If anything this game does the impossible and takes everything that makes Slime Rancher a wonderful game and vastly improves on it. It is an absolutely magical experience, even in early access.

Thank you to the team at Monomi Park. I cannot wait to see what the future still holds for the continuation and growth of Slime Rancher 2. It is a beautiful piece of media.

Short and unfinished at present, but on the whole, this is not just more of the same. It is a visual and mechanical improvement over the first Slime Rancher. Slime Rancher 2 is more focussed on exploration than the original; the maps are bigger, more beautiful and vastly more complex, and, in order to find resources to progress, you need to actively search for them. This is a significant improvement to the formula; it encourages you to take your time walking around the world, enjoying the scenery and playing with the slimes, and delivers an experience that is even more whimsical and therapeutic than the first game. 

Also, you can have snowball fights with the slimes :3

What can I say about Slime Rancher 2? It's a wiggly wonderland, filled with adorable slimes, both old and new. It has familiar mechanics, items and characters - and a beautiful new landscape to explore.  I only encountered one bug during my 24 hours of play time - which was fixed by restarting the game. I've played £50 games with more bugs and less content than the early access of Slime Rancher 2! 

On the whole, I found the story (so far) just as charming and heartfelt as the original's. It's clear that this is a direct sequel to Slime Rancher 1 - so if you want to play 2, I'd advise you to play through 1 first. 

All in all, I bought Slime Rancher 2 only an hour after I got the email announcing it's release, and I do not regret it at all. Like it's predecessor, it is charming, beautiful and so wonderfully peaceful that it's an instant cure for my anxiety. I can only look forward to the next update, whenever that may be.

No left-handed mouse support in menus. Game runs pretty poorly. Music is nice but gets pretty annoying after a bit, and never shuts-up so it's necessary to mute it in audio settings.

Personally, i'm not a fan of the pre-built habitation pod thing you spawn in. In the first game it felt less claustrophobic and idk - "ranchy" because you were in an open-air farm. Additionally, while this is marketed as a "next-gen" Slime Rancher experience, it generally feels the exact same with a fresh coat of paint. I'd have liked more freedom in customizing your ranch, like being able to place farms and buildings on my own.

I'm happy to have played such a wonderful game in my lifetime, and I want it to get better, so I'd like to give you three feedback points about what I've seen in the game that I think could be improved.
The first point is that I often get Instant Kill while feeding Crystal Slime, or faint when I take multiple damage in a short period of time even if my health point is at least 75.
The second point and the third point are both Tarr related, when I quickly clear the Tarr or when I catch a glimpse of the Tarr for a split second the background music will change to Tarr's music and continue for the same amount of time, I think if the music can slowly disappear at the moment when the Tarr is cleared or I actively step away from the Tarr instead of waiting for a fixed period of time to disappear, in short, I hope to shorten the minimum duration of the music that encounters the Tarr a little bit or make several variations of the music that encounters the Tarr so that the game experience will not be too monotonous.
Last but not least, my newly purchased laptop would suddenly stall when defeating Tarr due to Tarr's death effect, although this may have something to do with my own computer configuration.
That's all thank you for bringing such a good game, I hope you will consider my suggestions.

Monomi Park's newest installment in the Slime Rancher series is off to an excellent start. The biggest change I see in the game is quality of life changes to the controls. For me, the tools your character can use work more consistently and smoother than they did in the original Slime Rancher.  The game is in early access and I think it's heading in a great direction and can't wait to see how Monomi Park continues to shape the second saga of Slime Rancher. 

Wishes for the game:
-More creative customization for slime pens on the ranch. 
-Being able to receive letters from people in our personal lives again (I have not received one if it is in the game) 
-3rd person POV option (with such a beautiful character design, i'd love to see her!) 
-Further fleshed out story behind the planet itself 
-Lore about other regions in the slime rancher universe 
-Rare alternative versions of the slimes we have (example: pokemon shiny versions)  
-Pots we can plant the fruit/veggies in to use as decor around the farm

the short: ive cried like 6 times so far make of that what you will

actual review:
monomi park have upped their atmosphere game tenfold - and that's saying something, since SR1 was my comfort game. to start, the soundtrack is an absolute masterpiece: if anything in SR1 made you cry, expect to absolutely sob at the beauty of SR2. a wonderful balance of old, new and improved mechanics and slimes, all your old friends helping you out, and the promise of some REALLY interesting lore - the kind that keeps one hyped and speculating from the beginning. let me tell you, that unlock changed the game for me. brilliant way of implementing it.
also the map is massive? i feel like i've paid less than enough for the content so far, and more's still coming.

i upgraded my laptop between sessions of this game. even potato quality settings looked absolutely phenomenal (mildly more crashing, but still very pretty).
 
also, this is the most polished early-access game i've ever played or seen. idk what level of perfectionist the devs are on, but i've fallen through at MOST five walls, and they even made sure to put an invisible wall around the Secret Unfinished Spoiler Zone (i just had to. high place, climbing surfaces, you gotta.)

also, if the devs ever see this: thank you for the Ruins piano mix on the house menu radio. it brings me to tears every single time. the ruins, especially its opening puzzle area, have always been my favourite location and tracks in the first game, and i'm so glad to hear it's followed me here too.
Only played 3 hours so far its a fun gameplay loop and progress feels nice.

Played the first game obsessively and was SO excited to find out the sequel is out! I think I've only played 9hrs collectively so far (school, unfortunately) but I still love it! The art and graphics alone are enough for me to want to play this, it's such a BEAUTIFUL game. It is absolutely gorgeous and so cute! The scenery and the slimes improved so much from the first game, which I didn't think was possible. There's currently a disclaimer that it's in the beta version and they're rolling out features still, so it might experience bugs/crashing/etc. I haven't played that much but the only problem I've encountered so far is it crashing once, and I was able to reboot it immediately and play unobstructed. Overall I would absolutely recommend these games, they are so much fun and a lot deeper than you would expect. Absolutely beautiful game, thank you to everyone who worked on it!

Gonna say this. I still love the game, despite how "bare bones" and "unfinished" it is. I bought this day one early access release, as I loved playing the first edition of Slime Rancher. Unfortunately, the communication is absolutely horrible.

If you don't know already, Slime Rancher hasn't had a major update in over six months, and now we have a new post about what's to come next. Not an update, or at least a minor update to fix some bugs. My infuriation and many other fans of the game would have been at least more patient and happier if we got updates, or at the very least announcements on the progress of development, regardless of how long we have to wait.

I understand that Monomi Park is an indie game company that doesn't work off of crunch culture and fast development. However, it is inexcusable to be left dry in the dust as we receive no input or announcement, only to speculate what could come next.

To people reading this review, don't buy this game until it's fully completed or we finally have better communication. If you still want this game, buy it when it's on the 25% sale. Otherwise, just play Slime Rancher 1 if you haven't done so yet. To Monomi Park, I'm very worried for your future, especially on Slime Rancher 2. Please don't do this again, and I might consider changing my review.

I love this game. It is, at least for me, almost perfect. But it has some glaring issues that I simply can't ignore.

The game is beautiful, the music equally so. The slimes are just as adorable as they were in the first game, and seeing some new kinds of slimes, is always nice. But the game feels, far too fast, compared to the first game. Slimes become hungry much faster than in the first, and plants and crops grow, much faster, when compared to the first. Normally, this wouldn't be a problem for some games, but for this kind of game, it is. A very, large, problem.

This game wants you to explore the islands, the new world, and that's fine. They're all beautiful and fascinating, and I loved every second of exploring it. But the problem boils down to the absolute lack of automation that also ends up killing the desire to explore at the same time. While in the first game, this automation was unlocked slowly with bee drones that help manage your ranch from selling or stocking plorts, or feeding and managing your slimes. This game, as far as I've seen so far, doesn't have that yet. Keyword, being yet. 

This lack of automation means that you have to remain around the ranch to make money to unlock more things that become a near necessity to explore, and you need to explore to unlock newer things. But you never have time to explore. One thing that made the first game so wonderfully pleasant was that the game was, intentionally slow. The ranch was slow, the world, was slow. Exploring and gathering resources with drills and pumps, was slow. Everything was slow, so you had plenty of time to explore the world in your own, steady, slow, pace. But this game moves far too fast to allow that. If you take time to explore, your ranch falls into chaos. If you take time to tend to your ranch, you make no progress due to a lack of exploration. Ultimately leading you to have hundreds of thousands of "Dollars" to work with, but nothing to ultimately spend it on.

I do love this game, and I do recommend it as an experience. But I must warn you, its incomplete, and as a tremendously avid fan of the first game, I desperately hope this game gets some adjustments to make it more similar to the first. With a recent update, my save file randomly deleted itself, so I'm now going through the game a second time to explore it all again and my review may change. But for right now, I can only give this game an approximate 7/10. It's a great game, but its just not as good as the first yet.

great game. Reminded me of how much fun the 1st one was. I have nearly 10 hours of playtime and I've explored nearly all of the mainland (save for some hidden areas I may have missed), done all of the Gordos and with the exception of the recently released powderfall bluffs, gotten all the slimes, plorts and most of the capsules. I never looked up a guide so that should explain how that 10 hours is 10 hours well spent and not blown out of proportions. I enjoyed all of the things I did and was able to optimize my slime farms with largos and proper food sources and generally, had a great time. 
TL:DR, game is good, if you liked the first one, you'll like this one.

However nothing is perfect and I am a firm believer of this. the game is in early access so this is more feedback than criticism, but it has some issues. Definitely on the smaller side all things considered however. The current size of the ranch is way too small for the scope of the game. We only have access to half of the slimes right now and even with optimized slimes, you use up nearly 3/4ths of the ranch on slimes and their food sources alone, not including excess plot things like silos and duplicate slime plots (for more plorts). I imagine/hope the hub will be expanded in the future. The crafting system is cool but also a bit hard to work with due to several factors:
-no tracking of resources for specific recipes (IE 5/20 fire plorts) while out and about
-RNG factors for some resources like honey (which is a very crucial resource) makes some recipes very hard to craft
-by the time you can easily gather said resources, the upgrade is no longer needed

also, the new system of crafting tech and decor that can be placed out in the world seems very poorly thought out. Take the hydro cannon for example. The crafting cost for it is too great for its usefulness, and there is no reasonable place to use it. Where do you need it? The obvious answer might be the ranch but Tarr doesn't spawn there (unless you mistakenly put the wrong plorts in the wrong pen) so you're supposed to put it out in the world somewhere, but where? you have a hydro cannon strapped to your vacc-pack so why would you need to place and automatic turret anywhere? theres no reason for its existence. 
And unless I missed the capsule for this, a set of 2-way portals of a certain color would be a great idea imo. like 2 purple portals, you can set one in the ranch and one in the powderfall bluffs.

This brings me to my next issue, teleporters. I like the concept of the final gordo in a zone giving you access to a portal that makes travel to the region much faster, however WHY would you need to travel back there after 'beating' the final gordo? by then, most efficient players would already have all the slimes and farmable plants/animals in the region, thus making returning to the region pointless. Maybe I am in the upper percentile of players with optimizing (LOL) but I find it hard to believe some players are rejoicing at the idea of faster travel AFTER they've completed an area. its redundant.

Powderfall bluffs on that note is a huge pain to get to. Not only is the area super hard to find (too hard if you ask me) but it also is a LONG trek to get to from your ranch. (spoilers for where its hidden) [spoiler] even with the convinience of the fire zone teleporter, you still have to walk all the way to the crystal gordo spot, jump into the falls, walk through the cave, teleport (load zone), walk through another cave and then finally you're in the new zone. [/spoiler] The first time I went there, I saw some material caches on the side of a cliff with some stagnant air waves next to it (visual glitch I presume), so I jumped on these air waves thinking they were solid considering there was no other reasonable way to reach said materials and promptly fell and died. I considered how long it would take to get back, and considered turning off the game and I chose the latter. I did not do it out of rage, I was merely satisfied with my experience and didn't feel like it was worth running back to the new zone just for an hour or so more play time.

In the end, I still love this game. I patiently look forward to the full release and will most likely start a new playthrough at that time, and even then, what we have now is a fun little game. SR2 was originally planned as a DLC for sr1, and based on what we did find in the back end did set a few things as effectively copy and pasted from sr1. SR2 was created after some issues with how SR1's foundation didn't allow reasonable scaling beyond where it was and into the new goals they had.

Now that the background is out of the way - lets look at what we got as a result of that:
- we started with 1 additional biome and a few extra slimes over where sr1's early access started. With similar development time before the launch of early access. We got to keep slime science and we were loaded with more slimes immediately which is something.
- after about 11ish month now of development, we are at a point where sr1 in early access, with a smaller team, had 2 additional small side area expansions for biomes over where sr2 currently is. less slimes however.
- Limited actual communication as to what to expect since last november, and no significant update since febuary

Steam does lend itself to verify the game is still being developed, but that's the only reason i haven't really jumped on the board of 'its abandoned'. When your only source of information as to what to come is a third party in this relationship, and that's the only source there's been for months... you've got yourself issues. You'd think even with a no crunch environment we would see more progress in the updates, or at least communication on the progress, with a bigger team than a smaller one. Yet so far the smaller team they had back in early sr1 days is what i'd actually say wins out a bit... 

I might change my recommendation status if we see an actual improvement in the communication, but to go from what they used to be in sr1 to what they are now, just raises too many red flags for me to recommend spending more money on sr2 than sr1 was...

The game started off with such promise and optimism.  However, it's been almost 8 months since the last significant update and the devs are virtually radio-silent. It's absolutely heartbreaking, as I was a huge fan of the first game. This should have just been dlc like I had heard it was originally planned to be. Yes, I understand that the reason they had to make it a whole new game was because they ran into limitations with certain features. I would have honestly preferred if they just scrapped those features, because at least then maybe it would still be a fun thing. Yknow. At least maybe it wouldnt take 8+ months of dead silence.

And before anyone argues about "crunch"- I am absolutely on board with them not doing crunch workplace behaviours, but that doesn't excuse the lack of communication. You are asking for a pretty hefty amount of money for something that is in early access. The least I expect from a dev is communication, and we don't even get that.

**EDIT 8/19**

It was announced recently that  there is a Slime Rancher movie in the works.

I think it would be fair to say that they're heavily involved in this film venture, which would take away some of the staff's time from working on the game.

These developers simply don't have their priorities in order. They release this game in early access, but would rather focus on other things than finishing it.

I stand by my earlier statement. It's very unlikely that they're going to finish the development of this game.

**END OF EDIT**

**EDIT 8/8**

Yesterday, Monomi Park posted a road map on their site for what to expect of the full release. The road map is incredibly bare bones, only providing vague insights without any sort of time table, and doesn't tell us anything that we didn't already know almost a year ago.

I predict that there is severe issues going on with the company and wouldn't be surprised if we never see the full release.

**END OF EDIT**

It's been nearly a year since the early access launched and there's only a single (small) content update in that time. And what's here isn't exactly that good either. This game is merely a rehash of the first one without doing anything to really separate itself from it's predecessor and improve on what came before. 

There's way too little content here to justify the price tag. What's here can be played through in a few hours. Definitely not worth $30.

Lack of content would be fine if we had some kind of assurance that it will receive regular updates. Except, as said before, there's been only a single update since launch and it barely added anything.

The devs are keeping silent on anything regarding future content. There's been no progress updates, teasers, anything that would actually give their customers assurance that content is coming. Instead, whenever a developer responds in the forums, they can only provide vague statements and make excuses that 'it's hard to manage a growing team, and we're going to keep growing'.

Right now, there's no reason to buy this game. There's nothing here that you couldn't get out of the first game. People buy games in early access because they expect the game to actually continue being developed.

When (if) this game receives additional content, I will update this review to reflect that.

early access game so review is a light recommendation, but still a recommendation nonetheless

overall the gameplay loop of SR2 is a lot similar to SR1, but featuring a few new upgrades, some different flora and fauna, and of course the stars of the show- a whole new world full of new slimes. if SR1 was fun for you and you wanted more from it, then SR2 is definitely a good choice.

of course if you've never played slime rancher 1 and want to know if you can jump straight to this game- yes, it's fine to just hop right into SR2 (thought at time of writing this review i'd still recommend SR1 first, considering it's a full and finished game and SR2 is not).

overall, the gameplay loop involves exploring new areas, capturing slimes, building up your ranch with agriculture (for food) and slime pens to farm plorts (for money and upgrades), collecting natural resources (for upgrades), and passing obstacles to progression in the form of giant slimes that need to be fed until they burst and gates that can only be opened by a specific type of plort, as well as just generally having to explore an area to find the way through to more new stuff.

in general both slime rancher games are best suited to people who:
- enjoy resource collection/management and ranching slimes via optimizing those resources and manually ferrying food to the slime pens when needed
- exploring around an open, interconnected world via simple key/door puzzles and gated progression in the form of what are essentially resource type/amount checks
- enjoy management and simulation aspects of games more than combat and exploration (although the latter 2 are still present to a degree)

tl;dr: worth the price even in its early stage, but i hope to see more worlds and slimes of the game soon, as  right now SR2 can barely crack 10 hours of gameplay before you run out of new places to go and new things to find. if you're interested in the series then SR1 is a better starting place, but if you already played that and want to know if the sequel is worth the trouble, i'd say it is.

This is such a fantastic sequel to Slime Rancher because of how well it continues the story and how easy it is to follow even if you haven't explored The Far, Far Range yet. The player controls take about 30 seconds to learn which is pretty nifty; I haven't played Slime Rancher on PC before and I was a little surprised at how easy the movement and interface is. There's plenty that needs doing in this game as well as adorable new slimes to find and collect. The soundtrack is lovely and supplements the overall mood of the game brilliantly, and differs from that of the first game so that was a nice change- though the style stays the same. The art style is cute as always, you can count on Monomi Park to do that. Overall, I love this game and I think it was well worth the money.

Before getting this game, especially if you play on a laptop or somewhat potato computer, make ABSOLUTELY SURE your computer meets the system requirements!! Specifically the GPU. There is an area of the game called Starlight Strand, which when you enter this area, your game will crash if the GPU does not meet the requirements.

To make things very clear: just because you can play the first game DOES NOT mean you can play this one!!

Furthermore, if you do encounter this problem, you'd better hope it doesn't take you longer than 2 hours to get to this point of the game, or else you will not receive a refund from Steam (even if you request a refund the very same day you purchased it).

If you are somewhat tech illiterate (like me) I would recommend reading through the support and discussion pages on Steam before purchasing the game. You'll find instructions on how to check to make sure your computer meets the requirements and you won't be out however much money (I got it on sale, so thankfully didn't pay full price) you would have spent on the game, not knowing your computer can't actually play that one specific area. 

I wish I could recommend the game because it's a cute sequel to a game I greatly enjoy. Unfortunately I couldn't progress enough to rec it. 

Don't be dumb like me. Make absolutely sure your computer can play this game before buying. And even if you can play Slime Rancher, it DOES NOT necessarily mean you can play Slime Rancher 2!
