TL;DR at the bottom

I like this game. But it has its fair share of flaws. I do recommend this game, but I feel that it has a while to go before it reaches the height of its predecessor (which is self-explanatory for an early access game but it's more than just that)


Also, slight spoiler warning. Nothing major, but I feel comfortable saying I've seen most of what this game has to offer, so there might be things I talk about that a new player might not want to know. There are also a few things about the first game I mention here, so keep that in mind. But I've tried to keep most of the larger things about this game in particular secret.


The graphics and presentation are stunning, but I switched away from default settings quite a while ago and never looked back. They're very resource intensive and they kind of make the game an eyesore to play with how overwhelming they are. If you tone it down, it looks, feels, and plays a lot better.

There a few quality of life changes I appreciated, such as the removal of any grinding necessary for Slime Science or Treasure Pods - they're all there from the start. Granted, the upgrades do require you to get slime science resources now (and regular gadgets also require you to spend money), and while I found it to not be that big of an issue while playing, I do have to wonder how sane some of those requirements were. It definitely makes it hard for me to want to get some of the later upgrades, but it's hard to complain when the jetpack is basically the exact direction I want them to take the core gameplay loop in, (at least for a larger part of the game) and the extra tank and tank guard upgrades, which while something I didn't really want when I played the first game, are honestly great additions that help to cut down some of the tedium (even if I've never died, so I've never been able to use the Tank Guard, but it seems like a nice addition)
Some people have complained about the general lack of money sinks like the 7Zee Rewards Club, which is an opinion I don't particularly agree with, but if you liked the padding, then get ready to coat the entire map in decorations, because you've got to make it longer yourself this time around. Not a problem for me, though.

The environment and map design is better than it's ever been, with incredible detail and quite a few secrets that's an absolute joy to experience for the first time. Granted, the places aren't as memorable to me as SR1's personally, but I think the reason for that is that I haven't etched all the crevices, valleys , rivers, and caves into my brain yet. The jogs that you have to take to get to your ranch expansions do get pretty annoying, though. The main area you ranch in is also pretty sprawling, which isn't a problem to me, but something tells me it's because of the way I played this game, so I'd have to take a look at everything later, if/when I play the game the way that you're "supposed to". At the very least, that's a potential flaw you can bypass. Which is nice.

I've seen people raise complaints about the game's length, which - fair enough, the game is quite short in its current state but the game has also fairly recently been released in early access, so I don't think it'll be a problem for too long. 

The new slime designs, while cute and usually at least mechanically unique, are probably my biggest gripe with this game overall. Practically all of them are just based on animals, and while they don't stick out abysmally, many of the game's much more inventive areas feel like they would have slimes far more interesting than what we got. To me, it seems like the game keeps banking on returning old favorites instead of building its own diverse, new ecosystems of slimes for its unique areas. It might make some sense for the game's dreamlike aesthetic, but for me that's no excuse. Of course, this game is too much of a whimsical, fun, fantastical adventure to not have animal slimes, but I feel they really should've taken more time to make more unique slimes so that the roster could've had more diversity. Although, while they're still animals, I do at least enjoy how the [spoiler]Angler[/spoiler] and [spoiler]Flutter[/spoiler] slimes look. One of the slimes they introduced in the new update does feel like a step in the right direction, too, even if I'm not really a fan of it personally.

The area introduced in the new update was really cool, and I'm in love with the aesthetic, but it's a little on the small side and the slimes found there just don't really fit all that well. Some of the new designs weren't a perfect fit for their environment anyways, and the first game didn't exactly knock it out of the park on that front either, but reintroducing an old slime and giving it a new gimmick, while not bad, really needs some new, interesting, more unique slimes to go along with it. Here's hoping they give the place some more revisions and improvements later..

Since it's also important to note here, you can modify some of the ways the game works, and I absolutely love this. It's probably one of my favorite parts about this game. I played the game with Tarrs turned off, Ferals on, and an increased damage modifier. The fact that the game lets you play Tarr-less without sacrificing the aggressiveness of the Ferals is already an incredibly great decision, but allowing you to bump up or even turn down the amount of damage you get is even sweeter, and it makes going through Feral-inhabited areas without health and energy upgrades a risk to your own life if you increase difficulty. Going Tarr-less also means you can put a bunch of different largo types on your ranch to roam free and watch different types of slimes hanging out, replacing the mundane busywork of feeding corrals and harvesting plort collectors with a nice, chill walk through your lively ranch, surrounded by gelatinous friends. If you find regular ranching to be tedious, I highly suggest you play the game like this. It's just great stuff, something the first game is now slightly lacking in comparison, and something I don't see enough people talking about. The only thing that I think could make it better is if you had the option to give every slime one of the Hunter's signature traits and make any largo go feral after long enough, to help make the game a just a bit more tough, if you wanted to.


It's good, I might even call it great, or maybe something more, but it's still in Early Access and it's got quite a few flaws and bizarre, unnecessary changes, even if quite minor ones. (It's also not particularly revolutionary which isn't a problem to me but you know) I'd consider it an improvement, but it needs more time in the development oven first. Still, if you have 30 bucks to spare, and you're fine with Early Access games and sequels that are quite similar to their predecessors, I don't think you'll be disappointed.

I loved the first Slime Rancher. It was one of the few games that i would play for a very long time, mainly because it was overall pretty peaceful and didn't require a lot of linear progress. You can go at your own pace and unlock things in different orders. It definitely wasn't a high paced nor a high action game, but it always did a great job at taking my mind of things. It quickly became the game that I tend to play when life becomes stressful. 
Slime Rancher 2 has been all of that, and more. The graphics are gorgeous! It's more colorful then the first one. It feels like there are a bit less slimes then the first one, however I haven't counted, and of course the game isn't finished yet. The new slimes are absolutely adorable. I loved them putting a refinerary link out in the map for us, it definetly helped remind me that I could do that while exploring. The ranch and certain spots on the map have 10x more details. I'm not super fond of the large amount of tunnels/paths that lead nowhere, mainly located in the lab underneath our house, but they do look very pretty. As far as I know there's no rewards club or slime toys in this version. I would like the slime toys, simply because it made me feel a bit better about locking them in a small square. The water turret, that I most definitely didn't use, are infidelity more useful for this game. I found the large slimes escaping a lot when I would be off exploring and not being there to feed them. I'm not completely done exploring the world, but I'm happy to know the slime statues being in use way more in Slime Rancher 2. 
Overall the game has been great. There are still multiple ways to get into areas, and some ways to get around unlocking doors. There are still the little pods for gadgets and decorations. Most of the utilities have been gotten form the characters we call so far. We still get to communicate with Mochi and Bob and everyone, however trading isn't available. I would most likely rate the game a 9/10 in the cozy game category. It only being a nine because as I mentioned it feels like there are less types of slimes so far. It is definitely worth the money if you enjoyed Slime Rancher or are just looking for a chill calming game to play.

Alright, I have written a review of this game before however my opinion has changed.
In my old review I recommended this game, however almost a year later I have changed my mind. This game was something I had been waiting for, for ages maybe a few years I don’t remember when I found out. As soon as it came out I bought it, but was disappointed to say the least. 
Here are my reasons why you may or may not want the game: 
Pros:
- The graphics are beautiful and defiantly an upgrade from the last game, I spent ages just admiring the scenery and graphics. 
- The adventuring feels like the best parts of the first game combined into one game, its fun to have to solve puzzles to get to the next stage in the game it also adds more hours to play.
- You do not need to play the first game to enjoy this, the story does continue but it’s not that connected. 

Cons:
- Its small, there is not a lot of content and while I can play slime rancher 1 for hours over and over, it just lacks charm in this one. There are not a lot of different biomes like the first, it feels like your getting lost in a maze that looks pretty much the same all over. 
- The game does have some glitches (to be expected in early access and a lot have been fixed.)
- Where is the new content? Perhaps I had been in the wrong to be under the assumption that there would be new slimes quite new on, that was what I heard and maybe that was just a rumour, however not much has been added almost a year later which is disappointing. 

Summary:
I enjoy this game, Slime Rancher will always hold a special place in my heart however the sequel just wasn’t the satisfying the urge to get new content for Slime Rancher 2. Like I said before this feels more like a new map with a few unique slimes rather then a sequel. I do not recommend spending money on this game until there is more content.
I defiantly do not regret spending money on this game and I’m sure there is much more content to await however I’m just disappointed I have yet to see anything.
Perhaps I am comparing this too much to the past game but that was just what I have experienced throughout my game play.

I think that this game is absolutely a masterpiece but as most early access games, just not a lot of content at the moment to make it worth the price, if you are coming back as somebody who played the first game I do recommend this to you, but not those who want a NEW game, I would recommend you to play the first one instead.

Pros: 
> Tanuki Slimes.
> Really cute relaxing Game. 
> Story is very cute.
> There is a LOT of content, if you spread out your playtime.

Cons: 
> If you don't spread out your playtime, then you can finish all content in around 18-20 hours.
> Like any other farming game, feeding/collecting slimes can be extremely repetitive.
> No multiplayer. (I do think there is a way to incorporate it, which would add a aspect to the game that would be way more enjoyable.)

Overall:
> When you play this game for the first time it will be EXTREMELY fun and comforting. However I find that the motions of farming/feeding/collecting from your slimes after a bit is extremely repetitive, and can be boring. Playing on different saves and difficult can scrub away at it. I do get on this game again when I see new content as been added, I do recommend this game. Personally, I found it to be EXTREMELY fun when I played it on stream for the first time on release.

I've been an avid lover of the first Slime Rancher game since about 2017. When I heard that Slime Rancher 2 came out, I was BEYOND excited for the second one. Despite it being in early access, I am in love with this game. Maybe it's because I'm biased from the first, but this easily makes it in my top ten favorite games. I'm so excited for the full release, and I'm hoping that there's gonna be more interactions with other NPCs like Ogden or Viktor later in the story (I haven't progressed too much in the actual story because I keep getting distracted by the BEAUTIFUL aesthetics), or maybe even introduce new NPCs entirely. The only problem I have with this game is that it runs pretty slowly sometimes, if that makes sense. I guess saying it can be laggy is a better description. I had this problem with the first one on my laptop, Xbox, and on my switch as well, but it's not to the point that it's unplayable, it's only ever now and again. I still would recommend this to anyone looking for a relaxing and peaceful game.

It’s ok.

- The falling in water being a “death” thing is pretty rough and made me not want to explore things. Looked away from my screen for a minute and lost 40min of resources.
- Having to walk back and forth all the time is pretty annoying. I want to go explore new areas but needing top back and feed slimes was a bit exhausting. Some means of knowing the status of the slime back home might allow for longer journeys with confidence. 
- does the base need to be soo huge and spread out? 
- story wise I had no idea what was going on, I did not play the previous game but feel I need more information on who these characters are and what happened in the previous games.
- the map is helpful but it would be nice if I could mark locked doors, nodes ext. 
- I pretty quickly ended up with heaps of money and nothing to do with it. Even after unlocking all of the areas.Not really motivated to make more corrals because that’d have led to more work and less exploration. 

Suggestions

- optional extended intro for those who haven't played game 1, or at least a written account that is readable by the player.
- a character guide 
- a corral /pen upgrade to freeze everything, this way if we want to focus on exploration we can just shut down the ranch for a bit 
- cheaper warps and more of them, maybe a 2 way warp
- free warp points in the ranch

I've got nearly 100 hours in Slime Rancher 1, a game I heavily enjoyed the experience of and played through multiple times. My viewpoint will mostly be comparing SR2 to SR1. SR2 feels like it's having a bit of an identity crisis, struggling to distinguish itself from SR1. 90% of the game is basically the same, with the exception of a few new slimes to collect (and some missing as of right now), a new map and a change to how resources are collected. 

The gameplay is largely the same, so if you're coming  from SR1 and hoping for some larger improvements or changes, this game isn't for you. It's heavily leaning on exploration and the busywork of slime farming. There is even less of a story than SR1 (which was one of the motivating factors for me in playing SR1). SR2's story is told in the same way with notes scattered around the world, but each note feels far less impactful and more like meaningless drivel in a lot of cases.

I could go on, but the point I'm trying to get across should be clear at this point. I've already had enough of SR1 and SR2 doesn't offer enough for me me to want to invest my time in it. People interested in SR2 but haven't played SR1 I think should just go buy SR1. SR2 is still in early access, so the devs could add enough to change my opinion, but for now, it's not worth the money or the time.

Run Back-and-Forth Simulator

1) This game is extremely tedious early on. There is too much redundant running due to limited inventory space (you have 4 slots starting). Early game teleporters are in limited supply and one-way back to base only... reducing your running around by only a fraction when you consider that there is so much more to explore. If you want to re-place a teleporter, you have to completely destroy it and make a new one so have fun RUNNING around in search for the resources again. Sucks if you accidentally put it in an un-ideal place.

2) Caring for slimes imprisoned on your ranch is also SUPER tedious. Automation tools required. Micromanaging crops, feeding, gathering, and selling plorts gets old real fast. Unfortunately, if you want to make any money at a decent rate, you have to go through this process. Money is required for pretty much all upgrades, so you desperately need it.

3) There is no clear objective system as far as the story and unlocking new areas goes. I had to google whether I was missing something or if the other areas of the map just were not available yet. If you still feel like playing at this point, I recommend waiting till the full version is out.

4) Last minor observation is how the game makes all these optional craftable decorations available to you. When resources are a pain to gather, it is smarter to prioritize the upgrades that allow you to travel efficiently and expand your inventory. Who is actually creating decorative rocks and grass in the first few hours of gameplay? If it was not for the fact that the hidden chests around the map sometimes hold critical upgrade components, I would not bother opening them. Also, have fun wondering whether the chests you missed have something useful in them. You will probably be referring to the internet to make sure you did not leave something good behind.

I remember buying the first game for my sister a few years back. Didn't think much of it at the time, but I thought it would be a nice gift for her. I remember seeing her playing it from time to time, the message indicating that she'd started playing it popping up on the corner of my screen. There was always a certain small pride in seeing that, because to me it meant that she was enjoying my gift.
Last September she committed suicide.

After everything had more or less settled down from that, I sat down and booted up her computer. All that was on there was Chrome, Steam, Word, and a few games. One of them, of course, was Slime Rancher
She had played this game to pieces, clocking over 170 hours and owning practically everything the game had to offer. She had used every square inch to its maximum potential, and was making ridiculous amounts of loot. It was only then did I see just how much she loved my present. No other game she played quite captured her affection as much as this one. None of her friends really knew about it, however; it seems like she preferred to keep it to herself. Like it was her own little bit of heaven she could turn to whenever she wanted.

And because of that, I can't help but smile whenever I play this game.

I cannot recommend it enough; every bit of hard work the developer put into this masterpiece shows in every single aspect. The music is catchy and memorable (I'll often find myself humming certain tunes from it), the world feels lived-in and natural, and the gameplay is incredibly laid back and enjoyable. It's hard to stop once I get invested in the game; minutes can easily turn into several hours.

Slime Rancher 2 is beautiful in every way. At first glance, the map is colourful, bright and filled with cute slimes, some old and some new. I adore the Batty Slimes and Flutter Slimes! 

In more detail, the game is constructed in a creative way, bringing colour (and cute slimes) into different locations: The Conservatory, Rainbow Fields, Starlight Strand, Ember Valley and Powderfall Bluffs. Each section has it's own unique properties. 

The Conservatory is home base, and where the money is made. I love the giant tree growing in the middle! The Rainbow Fields is the first colourful landscape that lies in front of the Conservatory, the start of our adventure and gateway to other locations. The new Cotton Slimes hop around, in search of vegetables to chomp down on (and merging with Pink Slimes to my great annoyance while gaining food and resources). 
Starlight Strand is my favourite part of Rainbow Island, displaying a bi-coloured pink and blue map that holds colourful flora, cave networks, ancient ruin and, uniquely native to the Strand, Flutter Slimes. 
Ember Valley is next, bringing in warm orange and cool blue/violet tones with a Jurassic landscape. Batty Slimes are a more common occurrence in the Valley, and we get to see our old Fire Slime friends too! Powderfall Bluffs was added in the recent update. I have taken a great liking to any map involving a winter landscape filled with snow and ice. Powderfall does not disappoint. It hosts a stunning snowy landscape, complete with a large mountain, prehistoric plant life surrounding hot springs and a few secret spots. How can I forget the Saber Slimes, that have made a comeback?

The mechanics are similar to the first game, so starting business at the Conservatory was easy. I do like the new mechanic of physically collecting resources, it adds another layer of farming and exploration. Also the fact that the Fabricator is right under the Conservatory is convenient. Gordo popping is always a blast! I love the new selection of our giant pals, and I'll admit finding a few of them had me stumped. 

Game play is incredibly smooth for Early Access, any bugs I've come across have been minor (such as hens stuck in walls). Exploring is made easy, with the keenest ranchers being able to get to the highest peaks in the map with sheer will and a jet-pack. 

Sound design in general is good, enough to immerse me in the wiggly adventure. Oh, and everyone loves our bouncing little pals peeps and squeaks!

Next, the soundtrack is my main motivator, filled with emotional pieces from Harry Mack, probably one of the best composers I listen to. Seriously, the Ember Valley and Starlight Strand tracks are so cheery! I love the range of the soundtrack too. Like the first game, Harry composed several pieces for each biome, depending on the time (Day, Night, Late Night), and adding his own, Serene and Dreaming. These pieces all follow the leitmotif of the respective day theme, but with noticeable differences, such as pace and selection of instruments. 

Story wise, it seems unfinished at the time of my playthrough, which is understandable in Early Access. I'm excited to see how the story evolves in the final release!

I 100% recommend buying this for a peaceful and colourful adventure on Rainbow Island. I find myself completely immersed in any task, admiring the different landscapes and beautifully constructed soundtrack. The new slimes are incredibly cute and I can't wait for future updates!

It's just like the first Slime Rancher, and I don't think that's a good thing. Slime Rancher 2 could (should?) have been a DLC.

You'd think if someone made a sequel there would be something to set it apart from its predecessor but SR2 has the exact same gameplay, the only thing that is different is that now everything is harder to tell apart because nearly every surface is the same color. I had to tone down a lot of the settings - especially the chromatic aberration at the edges - because I had a hard time telling what was what. I get that they wanted to make a colorful game - they did succeed in that - but when everything is colorful, nothing is. It just makes stuff hard to look at, and this came apparent after a couple hours of continuous gameplay.

Another new thing is of course a few new types of slimes but... This game is suffering of all the same tedious things as the first game; namely the limited inventory and having to go back and forth the same goddamn routes. Arguably probably even worse this time because you have to harvest materials by hand instead of automating it. By 5 hours into the game I would have wanted to get something a little... "more", little something new that would set it apart, something that would warrant it being a game of its own and not just a coat of rainbow paint. Something that would make my life as a Slime Rancher a bit easier - some new gadgets or tools or something. As a player I would like to feel that the devs respect my time, but that wasn't the case here. Equally the world felt stagnant - I was growing increasingly frustrated when all the NPCs I heard of were the same ones from the original game. Could've at least introduced a couple new faces to make things more interesting?

Oh, and I think this game poorly on-boards the player. Having played the original SR I knew what I was supposed to do and how things function (especially because everything is pretty much identical to the original). But the player is just dropped in with minimal info about what to do. Speaking of, I found myself wanting a little more in-depth descriptions for the entries in Slimepedia than just a couple words (usually nothing but a pun).

Some performance issues are present as well, the framerate drops near the teleports and whenever blasting Tarrs with water.

I dunno. I loved the original SR but this sequel isn't different enough to be interesting. It will have to get some radical changes later in the development if it wants to grab my attention better.

And on a personal note, I would wish for map pins...

As someone who didn't play the first Slime Rancher, I was pleasantly surprised by the tranquility and joy that Slime Rancher 2 brought to my gaming sessions. This early access sequel offers a unique and calming experience centered around collecting slimes.

From the moment I started playing Slime Rancher 2, I was immediately drawn into its enchanting world. The game provided the perfect escape from the stresses of daily life, allowing me to immerse myself in a peaceful and delightful adventure. The simple act of collecting slimes and tending to my ranch became a source of relaxation and joy.

The visuals in Slime Rancher 2 are visually pleasing, with vibrant colors and charming environments that make exploring the game world a pleasure. Each area I visited was filled with its own distinct beauty, from lush green pastures to mysterious and otherworldly landscapes. It was a treat for the eyes and added to the overall serenity of the experience.

One of the aspects that stood out to me was the variety of slimes I encountered throughout my journey. Each slime I encountered was unique, making them a joy to observe and interact with. From mischievous troublemakers to adorable and friendly creatures, the slimes added a sense of wonder and discovery to the game.

While I can't compare Slime Rancher 2 to its predecessor, I found the gameplay loop of exploration, resource collection, and slime management to be incredibly satisfying. The game struck the perfect balance between simplicity and depth, allowing me to easily grasp the mechanics while still providing enough depth to keep me engaged. It was a pleasure to experiment with different slime combinations and witness the results.

Although Slime Rancher 2 is still in its early access stage, I was impressed by its polished gameplay and overall stability. The developers have created a tranquil and enjoyable experience that offers a welcome break from the intensity of other games on the market. However, I do hope to see the addition of features like NPCs and multiplayer options in future updates to further enrich the world and allow for shared experiences with friends.

In conclusion, Slime Rancher 2 provided me with a serene and delightful journey into the world of slime collecting. I found it to be an accessible and enjoyable experience that offered a much-needed break from the demands of everyday life. The captivating visuals, charming slimes, and relaxing gameplay loop make Slime Rancher 2 a worthwhile adventure for anyone seeking a peaceful and engaging gaming experience.

Essentially the first game, but with a different map and a couple different slimes that don't actually change the gameplay meaningfully. Development speed is somehow going at a snail's pace despite that, and when questioned on it, they use livestreams as evidence that they haven't given up.

The game itself lacks quality of life features and a break from the grinding the first desperately needed, and instead focuses mainly on exploring new environments you can hardly interact with.

The developers are burned out and gave up, or the first game was a fluke. Either way, this feels like a shameless cash grab at this point, and I regret giving them my money.

If you like the first game, you will most likely like this one too. the game is very similar to the first game, although the map is different on how you unlock new areas and gather materials, etc.

Materials are now found around the map, instead of using drills. I'm personally not too bothered about this, as it adds more of a reason to run around the map to gather them, although it is time consuming if you don't know where to find them.

Upgrades take a lot longer to get too, as you now need plorts and other materials to make them, including coins. (im not too sure if the first game required it too, it's been like 4 years lol.)

New areas are unlocked with teleporters now, usually having a gordo slime covering it. instead of using slime keys

More or less, it's a great game, like the first one. Can't wait for the full release.

[h1]Asinine Rancher[/h1]
Pros: [b]#1.[/b] I haven't found any yet.

Cons: [b]#1.[/b] No fast travel system.
[b]#2.[/b] Terrible inventory system. You can only carry 4 types of items and nothing more... so your inventory can be full after carrying just 4 single items. It's the stupidest inventory mechanic possible.
[b]#3.[/b] Loot that's on the ground disappears after some time has passed.
[b]#4.[/b] Carried loot disappears when you die. That's massively punishing. And believe me, with this terrible inventory system, you're going to be leaving A LOT of loot on the ground, so this is a big problem.
[b]#5.[/b] No tutorial to speak of. Almost nothing is explained at all.
[b]#6.[/b] Runs very poorly. I get less frames per sec in this game on medium, than I do on high in Cyberpunk 2077.
[b]#7.[/b] The regional pricing is really bad and the game is heavily over-priced in many countries
[b]#8.[/b] The game is for sale in russia

This game has beautiful and diverse environments that are a real treat to explore, and wonderful and cute slimes with diverse and interesting characteristics. I love just roaming the map and collecting. However, as with all early access games it doesn't feel complete. The areas for exploration and slime designs are amazing, but the actual ranching feels monotonous. It feels like no matter what slime you get the solution for ranching them is to largo them with something relatively docile and easy to feed like honey, bat, cotton, etc... A great example of this are the flutter slimes. They eat only a nectar that you can't farm, but provide a calming aura when they eat, however as the player this creates heavily incentives to just largo it and forget because you can't get a steady food source for them. On top of this, despite the slimepedia suggesting to let the slimes roam around your ranch there isn't really any way to let them do so. If you were able to restict slimes to an area of your ranch, make flutter slimes unlargoable and make limmited of their food source, like an upgrade to a pen to add the flower to make use of the aura, they would be the unique tool there design has potential for. But, for now they, like many other slimes, are amazing in the wild and lose most, or all their character when they come back to the ranch.

I've adored this since the first game years ago, so most of my light "criticisms" could be chalked up to the early access part of the game right now, or that the game isn't a one to one copy of the first. But here are my thoughts:

I believe the game should have more ways to use your money, with sr1 (slime rancher 1) you'd of course unlock the different areas which is how the second game approaches this, but you had the upgrade system for your ranch (i don't remember it specific name). But with this addition you can only spend your money on upgrades for your tools, but due to how easy it is to get these materials now as they are scattered everywhere as well as how they replenish every few days, youd expect the cost of them to be higher to account for this but it doesnt. (Though maybe my levels arent high enough)

I also believe that either how easy the jetpack is to obtain, or how strong it is makes upgrading it seems a bit void, as after one upgrade i can reach anywhere as without it your soft locked. And i think it takes away the feeling of explorartin a touch to me. 

This may be nit picky but i believe that some tunnels are less helpful than others, and felt almost useless to unlock. Though i would say the burts of water that would push you upwards, especially from one of the gordo slims felt very rewarding.

This may be because of the size of the game, which is a feat and i cant thank enough as some sections felt incredibly rewarding to explore, this being pointed specifically towards the first gordo slime. But i do feel like ive had to use my map so much more in this, it may be the obvious of again its size, or i haven't gotten used to it but i feel like the environments arent specific enough or varied enough, as in my opinion in the first game each area felt so difference if i picked a random screen shot i could tell you where in the game i was from its colour, tone and fauna.Yet i feel many areas blend together almost as two areas stand out the most to me.

One thing i wouldve liked is more reasons for the pond area, as from my point in the game it can only be used for puddle slimes at the moment, and id assume if it was anything like the first game the incinerator would follow the same trend.

Though these are all my opinions i want to say the adding of the tanuki slime has been one of the most funnest moments within all of my play time and with slime rancher 1, One thing i can endlessly praise the game for is how blind i am to it, exploring and learning the mechnics have been amazing and i cant thank the team enough.

Cute game. My son and I play together - game is not multiplayer - we just sit together and take turns since he's fairly young. Game is colorful, very entertaining, kid friendly - shooting water is your "weapon" - and simply, just a good time. You can capture a multitude of different slimes which you then need to build a housing structure (cage, but a nice one) to house the lil critters. You then need to supply it with food, typically meat in the form of chickens, vegetables or fruit. You can craft chicken pens to raise your own, you can build farms to grow your own fruit/vegetables. 

Once you have housing and food for your new slimy friends, you then feed the lil boogers. Once they eat, they create a "plort" which has multiple uses. One, it makes money. Two, you need certain plorts for crafting different tools/gadgets. Lastly, you can use plorts to combine slime species. For example, the most basic slime is a pink slime. They have the most forgiving diet, they eat anything. Some slimes, like the Flutter Slime, will only eat dew, which is difficult to find and you cannot farm/grow it. So, to make keeping Flutter slimes easier on yourself, you would feed the Flutter slime a plort from the pink slime. It then has the attributes of both slimes. They combine their diets, so the Flutter slime can now eat anything and they combine their appearance, in this instance it would turn into a pink largo(generic name of combined slime species) with butterfly features. 

All in all, the game is very entertaining, easy to play and if you have a young one who is interested in some gaming, this title is certainly one you could play with your kiddo at any age level. If you like to play creative and well done FPS games, check this one out.

As someone who absolutely adores the first Slime Rancher game, I can say with complete confidence that I fully support and cannot wait for the full release of this game! Monomi Park clearly has a passion for this style and genre of game which I find exceptionally enthralling and delightful. The gameplay is smooth, the graphics are as dream-like as ever, and the new mechanics implemented are working rather well for myself! I'll admit, the expanded science system is taking some getting used to but I still find it entertaining and enjoyable to a degree. The game so far is still in early access making it difficult to say there are no issues, but issues I have with this game are completely overshadowed by the trust I have in this company and the potential for the game as a whole!

Little suggestion: with such a different landmass which may be difficult to navigate, perhaps consider implementing a mini map which players can choose to display- perhaps craft on their own- so as to avoid the frustration with retracing and getting lost. Maybe this is already a thing and I just haven't seen it yet but, if it isn't, give it some thought!

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Slime Rancher 2, the highly anticipated sequel to the beloved original, has exceeded all expectations and solidified itself as a true gem in the world of gaming. As a dedicated fan of the original, I can confidently say that this sequel captures everything I loved about the first game and expands upon it in exciting and innovative ways.

One of the standout features of Slime Rancher 2 is the charming and vibrant world it presents. The visuals are absolutely stunning, with vivid colors and beautiful landscapes that make exploring the Far, Far Range a delightful experience. The attention to detail is remarkable, and each area feels distinct and alive, teeming with unique flora and fauna.

The core game-play loop of slime ranching remains as addictive as ever. As a player, you'll find yourself venturing out into the wild to capture and collect adorable slimes, each with their own characteristics and quirks. Managing your slime ranch, constructing new facilities, and taking care of the slimes' needs is a satisfying and rewarding experience. The addition of new types of slimes and resources adds depth to the game-play, ensuring that there's always something new to discover and experiment with.

One of the most significant improvements in Slime Rancher 2 is the expanded world and increased interactivity. The addition of new areas to explore, such as dense forests and mysterious underground caves, adds a sense of wonder and adventure to the game. The expanded range of activities and tasks available keeps the game-play fresh and engaging, offering more opportunities for creativity and exploration.

The game's progression system is well-paced, striking a perfect balance between providing new challenges and allowing players to explore at their own pace. The introduction of new gadgets and upgrades allows for greater customization and enhances the game-play experience. The well-designed tutorial ensures that both newcomers and returning players can jump right into the action, while still offering enough depth to satisfy experienced slime ranchers.

Beyond the engaging game-play and stunning visuals, Slime Rancher 2 boasts a delightful soundtrack that complements the whimsical atmosphere of the game. The sound design is top-notch, with charming sound effects that bring the slimes and the world around them to life.

Furthermore, the developers have shown great dedication to the community, actively listening to feedback and implementing improvements and updates. This commitment to player satisfaction is commendable and speaks volumes about the passion behind the game.

I orginally pirated the game and let it sit, like, forever, after playing it for a week or so, that was ver 1.1.2 or something I believe, in the time that has passed since then,(september ish I believe.) the game has made a snails pace of progress. I decided to actually get the game as a friend of mine had slime rancher and was planning to purchase slime rancher 2. I was understandly disppointed with the amount of content I got for 30$. Of course it's still in early access which forgives it somewhat, but honestly, first problem is that you gain coins really fast, and it quickly becomes more of a hassle to go around collecting slime plorts(which takes quite a bit in it's own right), coins have limited uses for the amount you can gain. The lack of challage of any sort is pretty annoying, finding new things can be fun, though the biggest obstacle was falling into the slime sea, the slimes are rarely anywhere near as deadly(Even in the ranch most slimes are easy to care for, especially with too many reasources), In the end. The game is lacking much challage and gets boring rather quickly, at the moment of this review it's not worth it's high price tag but, that may change in the future.

While the devs have already finished and polished some aspects of the game (like the graphics and soundtrack) , it does have its cons. During my first save, I would always crash at the teleporter to Starlight Strand. Its also harder to run on lower end devices unlike the first game. Even at the lowest setting, when i use my laptop instead of my pc, I would get a maximum of 20ish fps. The game is in early access though, so expect this to change. I'm now on my second save and it seems to be running better.

Overall, I would give it a 6/10. Dont buy it yet unless its on sale or its out of Early Access. Or if you have a high end PC

As of right now, I can't really say this game is worth playing in early access.

Don't get me wrong, it is just as good as the first one but... The additional features that the games provide currently feel more like they should have been DLC content rather than branded as a whole /new/ game because of how minimal they are. The story is pretty hard to follow in my opinion, feels like its barely there and I finished it a lot quicker than I expected versus the past game. The exploration is very very minimal to me, there isn't a lot of places to unlock and most of the big bois really only unlock unrelated items. And to top it all off; to me personally, the lack of any updates that actually add to the game rather than decor and already existing content from the past game really draws me away from it.

So if you're a returning Slime Rancher player, stick with the first game for now. I'm still hoping this game with take a good route.

After sinking so many hours into Slime Rancher, the moment I had heard there was going to be a second, I knew I had to buy it. The first game was a wonderful, beautiful, and very fun experience, and I just knew this was going to be the same. New locations, new slimes, new memories to be made. 

The only thing I truly wish from this game is for it to be multiplayer. When I was playing the first, all I could think is how much fun my girlfriend and I would have owning and taking care of a ranch together. I'm sure adding multiplayer might mess with the story line a little, but a separate multiplayer mode would be a nice addition. Not only do I want new memories, but ones with her as well.

Another thing; I've noticed that a lot of sounds stop working the longer I play i.e. the chickens no longer cluck or chirp or ruffle their feathers, the slimes don't make their splat or spinning up sounds, I can't hear myself run, etc. 

TLDR: multiplayer would be nice imo, sounds stop working after long game sessions.

Maybe some of this is due to early access... but it feels like more of a grind with less of a purpose than the original. I actually went back and played the original out of curiosity -- it immediately has a more interesting gameplay loop. 

While I like the idea of the fabricator, getting the required components (that are not plorts) is a grind. And you unlock certain upgrades at total random it seems like (like the increased backpack size) which just makes it even more grind-y at certain points. And the warp portals are locked behind the fabricator as well, so that doesn't help you navigate the massive world. There are certain things I unlocked like near the end of the game (signs to place where you find fruits/veggies) that are entirely useless by that point. Pretty much useless at any time, because there is an ABUNDANCE of everything, everywhere. Nothing feels rare, it just takes forever to gather it all.

I love the first game a lot, and by god I love Slime Rancher 2 a lot as well. Everything in this game is on-par with, if not an improvement to the first game. The soundtrack is phenomenal, I love the whimsical music in Rainbow Island, It was fantastic in the original game and it's fantastic here, each track perfectly going with the region it plays in. The environments are drop dead gorgeous, and every turn is background material.
        And they did Not forget about exploration, as each region is Littered with secret passage ways, collectibles, and gordos. This combined with how beautiful everything is really makes wondering around an absolute treat. Ranching slimes is pretty much the same as ever, though without the automation drones at the moment. Science and resource collecting is available from the start, and I like the changes they made to resource collection, where instead of creating a machine, placing it in an area, and waiting for it to slowly expel resources like the first game, in here you just siphon resources from various deposits scattered around the place that regenerate by the next time you visit.
        Overall, would very highly recommend it in its current form. If you're just wanting more of the same Slime Rancher experience, this game is perfect for you. The only minor nitpicks i have really is; The starting area in Ember Valley doesn't have much to look at, just a lot of dull yellow grass and gray cliff faces. The way you enter each environment is just by walking through a portal, which I think diminishes a little bit from the presentation of entering a new region that you experienced in the first game. Though, I think the fact you can see each region and its significant landmarks from Rainbow Valley is cool.

Slime Rancher 2 successfully captures the charm and addictive gameplay of its predecessor while introducing new elements to keep players engaged. With its enchanting visuals, enjoyable gameplay loop, and a world brimming with surprises, it is a worthy sequel that will undoubtedly captivate both longtime fans and newcomers alike. If you're seeking a whimsical and heartwarming adventure, Slime Rancher 2 is a game that shouldn't be missed.

One of the standout aspects of Slime Rancher 2 is its captivating visual design. The game is a true feast for the eyes, with its colorful and imaginative environments. From the lush greenery of the ranch to the alien landscapes, each location feels distinct and teeming with life. The charming slimes, which come in various shapes, sizes, and colors, are a joy to interact with, adding an endearing touch to the game's aesthetic.

The core gameplay loop remains largely unchanged from the original Slime Rancher. As a rancher, you must wrangle and care for different types of slimes, managing their needs and ensuring their well-being. The simple yet addictive mechanics of feeding, corralling, and breeding slimes are as enjoyable as ever. 

The soundtrack of Slime Rancher 2 deserves praise, as it beautifully complements the game's cheerful atmosphere. The whimsical tunes perfectly capture the essence of the game, enhancing the joyous moments and providing a calming backdrop during exploration. The sound effects are also well executed, from the playful squeaks of the slimes to the environmental audio cues.

Slime Rancher 2 is an absolutely delightful game that delivers a truly magical experience. From the vibrant and colourful world to the wide variety of slimes to collect and the immersive gameplay.

One of the best things about Slime Rancher 2 is the sheer number of different slimes you can collect and take care of. Each slime has its own unique personality and set of behaviours, which makes them all the more fun to interact with. The game has cool mechanics such as slime crossbreeding and ranch expansion.

The game's graphics are a amazing, with a whimsical, beautiful aesthetic that is both charming and immersive. The soundtrack is also a joy to listen to, with its upbeat and relaxing tunes that make it a perfect game to wind down to.

Overall, Slime Rancher 2 is an exquisitely designed game. With numerous improvements and additions to the original game, this sequel is a definite must-play for anyone who loves cute, colourful and engaging adventures.

Slime rancher 2 is one of the best games I've ever played, hands down, and it's still only in early release. I got the first Slime Rancher game during the Christmas of 2017, and have loved it ever since. Slime Rancher has been one of my best gaming experiences ever, and the second game has only ever raised my opinion of the series.

There are so many new features and places to explore. One of my favorites is the snowball machine, where you can start snowball fights with you and your slimes, which is super fun and silly. Not only that, the scenery is gorgeous, as well. The sunsets and sunrises we see in-game are almost as beautiful, if not, more beautiful than the ones we see in real life. The Rainbow Fields, Starlight Strand, Ember Valley, and Powderfull Bluffs are all diverse environments and are all stunning in their own ways.

The game also shows amazing diversity, A good handful of characters have dark skin and are all very ethnically diverse. In the previous game, there was also a character who was in love with Beatrix named Casey, who's gender was left intentionally ambiguous, which could signal that there was a queer relationship between them. All the characters have interesting personalities and backstories, despite the character not being relevant to the game all the time.

Overall, I would highly recommend this game. It's excellent and has always been a positive experience for me.

The game is really good as a follow up to the original, with a less interesting late game. The ever so helpful drones of the first game aren't there, so good luck managing an entire ranch. It's an enjoyable experience to be sure.

I like it, but stuff is too expensive to upgrade now, seeing as now you need gold AND plorts to upgrade the vac, this seems pretty silly since to get gold in the first place you need to sell the plorts, on top of this the market trading is no longer a thing from the looks of it so far. You remember that requests thing where you could send stuff requested to NPCs and then receive up to four items for completing the request? Yeah that doesn't exist any more from the looks of it so it's harder to progress to the point it feels less relaxing and more grindy now when compared to the original. I think we could do without the plort requirement for upgrading the vac to be honest, but that's just me...

On the plus side, there's even more slimes to collect and care for in this than in the orginal Slime Rancher game. Will be honest though I prefer the original simply because it feels less grindy and more relaxing. Would I return this game because of the grindiness? Probably not, but I see myself playing the original more when I want to relax because while it's still fun and keeps a lot of the original features, it's way too grindy when compared to the other one. Still recommend it though if you don't mind it being harder to upgrade stuff than in the previous one.

UPDATE: I played longer and actually once you know where to find everything you need (Slimes, Crops, Locations, etc.) it's actually a lot easier to upgrade stuff, however it still requires some grinding to get all the things you need since there is no minimap to help you from the looks of it, so you kind of just have to get familiar with where everything is to know how to get to certain places. They do have teleporters you can craft, but these teleporters need a lot of items to craft as well as it takes a while to actually unlock them.

Slime Rancher 2 in early access is almost as good as the first Slime Rancher as fully developed game.

There are still some minor issues. In my case those are following:
 - freezing graphics by the corral half full of deep brine (my fault, I suppose - corrals are meant for slimes, not resources); 
 - sometimes it is not possible to vacuum resources - have to spend some time, until I get the correct position, from which resources can be picked up (mostly at Powderfall Bluffs); 
 - resources fall into the water, even though vacpack is directed at them (and again - Powderfall Bluffs).

Overall, however, Slime Rancher 2 is a great game and I am absolutely sure, that it will be even more amazing, when fully released. I do reccommend it for everyone, who enjoyed first Slime Rancher.

P.S. I do not reccommend early access Slime Rancher 2 for those, who are too impatient to wait for full release and keep asking the same questions of when will there be added this or that. Just play any other game you like, until Slime Rancher 2 is fully released.

I'm amazed how good this game already is. If you enjoyed the first Slime Rancher then you'll most likely love this one too. Everything that made the first game so fun is in this game too. The joy of ranching, exploring, and crafting is just as prevalent in this game and far improved. More slime science, more fun, unique, and infectiously adorable slimes (and tons of cool new cute species, such as the Ring-tail and the Batty Slimes), and more beautiful areas to explore and uncover. The story so far has been engaging, and they brought back all our friendly familiar faces from the first game who now add so much to trying to uncover the mystery of the new island. And as much as I loved The Ranch, I have to say that Rainbow Island really blows it out of the water in terms of design, size, and exploration. It's so expansive and there's a ton of areas to explore with huge variations to them all. Even the individual islands like Starlight Strand and Powderfall Bluffs are so large and varied that you can find tons of different ecosystems on each one. The amount of content in the game already is far more worth than the price tag on the game, which I haven't been able to say for a lot of Early Access games... This game actually feels more complete than many final release games do, but with so much of the enormous game world/map still left uncovered, I feel there's a lot we have left to see from Monomi Park in this game.
I highly recommend this game. I rarely ever buy early access cause it's such a gamble, but I loved the first one so much that I gave this a chance and was not disappointed in the least. It's literally everything that made the first one so great, just bigger, better, and even more expanded upon. If you loved or liked the first one, I feel you're going to have a similarly great and enjoyable time with this game. It adds quite a bit, but doesn't really change the formula of the game much, and some people may find that a turn-off, especially if you didn't enjoy the first, but to me they had such a solid game that there really isn't a need to change it that much, so instead they just improved greatly on what they had, and they did an incredible job improving it.

The game isn't great. I must admit that it is gorgeous, even on a mid-end PC. But, unfortunately, most of what I've seen looks mostly the same. The world is a pastel blur with mix-matched colours everywhere that turns bland rather quickly.

The game itself feels and plays exactly like the first one does. It feels like a DLC to the original. If you just want more Slime Rancher, this game is for you. If you're looking for something new in the series, you might want to wait. Other than cramming a bunch of different concepts into the first area and adding more slimes that for the most part are reused or literally just animals, Slime Rancher 2 doesn't add much.

It's like the original, but with less incentive to do anything. It feels slower, and the lore messages scattered about the map are barely worth reading, as they're nearly the same as the first game but less personal. Other than that, the sense of progression isn't good either. You stumble around lost for a bit (because everything looks the same) until you find a treasure pod that you can open immediately, making the game feel linear and taking away the sense of re-exploration the first one had.

Tarr have somehow become even weaker than they were in the first game. In the original, they were one of the least threatening dangers, especially when compared to mosaic slimes, etc. In this game, they are borderline harmless. Most of the time, they won't even attack. Cranked the damage multiplier up to max, and the damage they did after staring at me for what felt like half an hour was bare bones.

The tutorial doesn't feel real. It gives you a message or two, and then tosses you out to do whatever in the first area. I felt little drive to keep playing after that, it just feels like the first one but with a large chunk missing.

In conclusion,
Please make more original slimes.

I've tried to play this game a million times and enjoy it but I just can't. I don't know what features they could expand on to make this game better but it feels like the fun and joy that the first Slime Rancher had is gone. There is also a HUGE issue with how motion sickness inducing this game is. I usually avoid first person games due to this, but the first Slime Rancher had no issues with making me sick. However, with Slime Rancher 2; 5 minutes of playing make me feel the urge to throw up everywhere. I don't know if its the harsh colour scheme, confusing layout or the limited options in the settings that make it so hard to play but the first game had none of these issues. I know it's early access but I expected something better then the original Slime Rancher - not a pastel rainbow induced copy, this could honestly just pass as a DLC world for the og. I'll be keeping an eye out for updates but as for now this game is not worth playing, I would recommend others to just buy the first Slime Rancher.

Absolutely loving SR2 so far, it's got the addicting game play from the first game with new gaps, galley's and grazes for my hungry adventure appetite.

I'm someone who will spend hours doing what the game doesn't want me to do... and what I have found is that climbing is as fun as ever, till you get to the top. And I don't mean the top where the gordo or the map data is.. I mean the tip top, so far you can't see the drop, the rocks become somewhat.. questionable.. and your only view is of fog and distant landmarks. I would absolutely adore if the devs would leave something up this far for those of us who work their way around invisible walls and odd canyons. A little "Are you happy now?" on a sign for example would make me so overjoyed. Though there wouldn't be many who see it, isn't it wonderful to leave easter eggs of sorts for those who do? Just a thought.... 0.0  :D

Other than that, general thoughts on the game as it evolves..

I would have loved to see more plots in the initial greenhouse, one or two just outside the walls perhaps on the sides? It just feels very cramped and the roads down to the separate areas make for long and annoying treks back and forward when your farming becomes too advanced (overflowing of sorts). Another thought on this is that it would be oh so fabulous for hoarders like myself if the house itself had storage, silos not only take up a whole slot but don't actually hold that much.. if the house storage is a no go, an extra upgrade for silos where it can hold say 300 instead of 100 in each slot would help significantly. 

Some other minor things are that you can' make slime toys or lil helper bees and those would really help when I'm off climbing some rock I shouldn't be and my crystal slimes are going mad on the farm without me.. so would love to see something similar to those return as a mechanic. There's also the lighting issue, I know that in a recent update it's been adjusted from paparazzi are bombarding me to now, coming out of the gaming cave in the middle of a summer afternoon.. still need to play with my lighting adjustments down, especially when playing at night/ in a dim room.

I'd also love to see more customisation of the general farm area. My money is expansive with no end, if only I had a capitalistic, million dollar paint job to spend it on..

My only other random thought that I can think of right now is how much I would love a para-glider... though in my heart I know that would be an impossible ask... *sad*

If you need an extra bug tester don't be shy devs ;D
Thank you for your amazing work! You guys show heaps of passion for this little world and I can't wait to see what's coming in future updates <3

If you guys haven't bought this already? I'd 100% say to do so. There's more than enough to play with for the price right now, and if you know you'll eventually cave (just admit it) then you may as well get it now and support it to get where it needs to go! Get slime ranchin' !!

Love and warm regards,

The game looks a lot better and there are some nice changes to progression that make exploration feel more worthwhile, but at this point, the differences and improvement are not large enough to warrant buying this game if you played the first one. I also feel like the way the map and its inhabitants are currently put together feels somewhat lazy and doesn't make much sense. There are two big islands outside the starting one, yet they both have a major overlap in the slimes present and even some overlap in the type of areas found there. I'm also not huge on the idea of just having teleporters you unlock as it makes the world design feel less cleverly connected than it could be, even if the moments of these teleporters opening up from afar is pretty cool. If you've played the first one the game is not currently worth it and doesn't seem like it will be.

So Slime Rancher 2 where to start. First off it feels the the first game, art style feel of the game and how amazing the different area's look. Since this game is still in early accesses am not going to talk about what is missing from the game compared to the first game. Some thing i will talk about is whats been added, as of this post 4 new and cool looking zones a few new cute slimes and new upgrades for you. the Story line so far is kinda bitter sweet but i enjoy it. over all for a 30$ price tag if you liked the Original Slime Rancher then this good chance will be right up your alley.
With that said i do have some concerns for the game over all. first off the area that is your base i feel is quite small, when you want to have all plot types and foods right now its not impossible to have it all but with out a further expansion to your base i don't see how you can have it all. also with the latest big update they added snowball's and snow ball fights witch i love however i can only do it with wild slimes. back home i cant do it witch makes me a bit sad. also as of right now there is no way to play with my slimes. i want to fun things with my slimes run around, perhaps a big slime farm area that will feed them but plots will be destroyed so i can play with a few of my favorite looking slimes. this game is fun but its kinda sad watching my slimes in there cages and no good reason to let them out. also resource gathering, while getting more tanks are nice and most resources fine to get you had better grind to get the more rare items for important upgrades. with no way to find them then a sound randomly in the wild you will be spending a few hours looking 1 or 2 rare spawns.
over all its a very promising game. i enjoyed the first one and this one so far is just a upgrade from that. while yes i have my concerns am not going to say this game is doomed to fail unless they add them all. so far its a upgrade with a lot going for it. is it worth the 30$ price tag? hard to say as of now but am enjoying it.

I ADORE Slime Rancher (1) and am excited to play this game and see what unfolds in terms of new discoveries. I like the gameplay in Slime Rancher 2 so far. I like the new graphics/art and the new slimes/resources. However this game runs way way more laggy on my computer than Slime Rancher (1). I experience a lot of dropped frames stuttering and freezing with this game that just isn't present when I play the original Slime Rancher. It could be my hardware, but I've dropped the settings as low as they can go (while keeping framerate high) and it still feels like I'm playing this game in slow-mo with intermittent freezing. Slime Rancher (1) plays smooth as butter on my computer with absolutely no lag and dropped frames. I wish Slime Rancher 2 played as smoothly so badly because I want to enjoy it as much as the first one! Part of what makes Slime Rancher so fun for me to play is the snappy quick movements I can do during gameplay and Slime Rancher 2 just isn't as fun for me because that's missing. Hopefully this gets fixed or I can play the game on a beefier computer sometime! (O:

The first Slime Rancher is my favorite game of all time. This one keeps the same feel entirely. I was honestly expecting it to feel like another dlc for the first game, but it really blew me away. The new resource collecting for slime science is more interactive now which I think was a very needed change from the first game. Also, the idea of upgrade parts being in pods around the map is great. You feel a lot more active in this game compared to the first. I that they kind of scrapped the whole slime key idea, it was good for the first game but the teleporters feel new and fresh, they remind me of the Glass Desert teleporter from the first game. I have come across a few bugs but that's to be expected in an early access game. 8/10

It's very frustrating reading all these reviews that only have to say UUUGHH IT'S NOT AS FINISHED AS THE FIRST ONE!!! IT'S NOT AS IN DEPTH AS THE FIRST ONE!!

No shit, guys. It's in EARLY ACCESS. It is BEING DEVELOPED AS YOU PLAY AND GIVE BACK FEEDBACK. Feedback is not saying 'weeeeh it's not finished sob'. We know. Stop.

Real feedback would be this;

Incredible graphics and very colorful; I like that there is an option to adjust gamma and brightness, which really saves your eyes in the long run!

New slimes are adorable, and a great path so far; I can't wait to see what new ones come. It's nice to see slimes with gimmicks or special attributes like the [spoiler] ringtail slimes needing to be in the dark or they turn into statues, [/spoiler]- I'd love to see more of this to make it feel more unique in slime gathering instead of just slapping a few in a cage and forgetting until they revolt.

I like that I can turn off ferals and the Tarr. [spoiler] I found that the sheer amount of slimes spawning all around made CONSTANT tarr due to them all eating eachother's plorts non-stop and it turned into a constant tarr fest with no end in sight. Yeesh.[/spoiler]

I do find the farm travel a bit time consuming, but nothing game breaking- Its just so very big, at first, and I felt like I spent more time running back and forth than exploring- but that gets easier with teleporters and more energy to sprint.

I also find that the jetpack tends to act a bit wonky. Sometimes, I'll aim straight up, just using the space key to move, and it'll make me slide along objects to the side, or just not propel me up at all. Even worse if I use directional keys at the same time. Gravity hates you in this! 

Everything said; THIS IS AN EARLY. ACCESS. DEVELOPING. GAME. Stop bitching that it isn't complete, or doesn't have enough variety, or isn't as vast. It won't be for a while. You are here to get involved with this game as it develops. Not shit on them for not providing you a perfectly finished game step one.

[i]Slime Rancher 2, a very anticipated sequel for me to say the least, I have thousands of hours on the console version and not nearly enough on pc for the original, I adore the original dearly it was always an escape for me.[/i]

So now you wanna know about the game itself, it’s stunning, its gorgeous, the grass changes colors under your feet while you watch slimes do the goofy shenanigans they always do like catapult into that slimy sea, it plays amazing, the controls feel very good on controller with good responses. 
Some new features like upgrading out vacpack and being able to have more slots available? 10/10. The amount of upgrades are great so far I look forward to see if we get more. 

[i]The slimes? Cute obv,[/i] im quite weak to the Bat and Yolky slimes, the new intricate needs of each slime is very fun and I like the more need for care. 
[b]THE ONLY[/b] glitches or bugs ive seen thus far is things getting stuck in the world, and the floor disappearing for a few seconds, thats it. It’s not a joke when they say its incredibly polished, especially for an early access game. 


[b]MY SUGGESTIONS:[/b]
[list]
[*]I’d like to see all OG slimes in the game again, we might we might not, it’s perfectly fine if we don’t I just think lore wise maybe the rad slimes and quantums and Dervishes would fit great into the game. 

[*]Ability to edit current standing corrals, remove certain things with a cost of money rather than demolishing entire plots to rebuild. I know keeping music boxes and shade roofs isnt a big deal I just like to be weird and detail oriented so i might be the only person who feels this way. 

[*]Solar based slimes? Slimes that need sunlight to live and survive? Probably complicated and weird but idk could be cool. Could be like lizard inspired. 

[*]Ice slimes, yeah thats really it.
[/list]

[h1]TLDR;[/h1] Fantastic game WELL worth the money, pratically stealing when its on sale and I can’t WAIT to see the finished game!

The game has been, overall, quite enjoyable, but there parts that are a bit disappointing, in my opinion.

The game looks great, that is undeniable. The islands are distinct from each other while still fitting the magical theme of this game (as apposed to the much less magical theme of the first game). The story has been, so far, quite good (even if it is a bit slow for each piece of info, but maybe that is just because I'm not at the conservatory much). I really like the drones  [spoiler]and fact that you can hack them to get more information[/spoiler] and having to feed Gordos to directly unlock sections rather than getting boxes of junk crops and slime keys to unlock doors (which were a bit buggy [I have unlocked all of the doors, but I somehow have 1 slime key left over]). The change from extractors with tiers to just running around and collecting the ore manually was an interesting one, but by no means bad (even if it did make me question my sanity the first times the ore node disappeared at some point after harvesting).

The islands are where I have most of my issues with the game. 
Each island has a completely different biome, which is good because it provides locations for all of the types of slimes (and each slime unique to each island feels like it belongs there), but it also makes the map (to me) feel more disjointed than the original Slime Rancher, which also had different zones (albeit not as extreme) that were blended together into one continuous land mass in a logical way.

You get to the islands with teleporters, which is a cool idea, but it can be difficult to just find some of them, let alone activate them (chiefly, the teleporter to get to frozen island, [spoiler]which is hidden behind a waterfall[/spoiler]).

After uncovering all of each island, it seemed like the map was smaller than the original game, which may just be because the playable area is split into four islands instead of two. With this in mind, there are also two large impassable (I've tried) walls, one in the volcanic zone and one in the magical zone, and (at least to me) it feels like I should be able to get past them and there should be more on the other side. This is especially true for the one in the volcanic area, which looks like a giant round door (to me), and it feels like the perfect place for an epic cinematic of the giant door going down into the lava, akin to slime gate (or whatever it was called) in the original game at the end of the Ruins. But instead of this, you feed a Gordo in a comparatively small doorway, and walk into a mostly empty room. All that is there are a couple of pods, some floodlights, and another flat wall.

Another point (loosely related to the islands) are the number of slimes. A lot of new slimes were added to fit the more magical theme, which they did, and other slimes were likewise removed because they did not fit the theme, which is understandable, but the net number of slimes has only increased by 1 from 17 to 18 and, strangely, the number of spaces on the Plort Market has increased from 22 to 34. This slight increase in the number of slimes when compared to the drastic 
increase in the number of spots in the Plort Market seems like either the developers have or had more planned, but it seems like it would probably be "had" since I don't see how they could add so many more slimes without building another game's worth of area to find them in, unless they just planned on finding ways to slap on some of the other slimes from the original game.

I know that this whole essay won't change anything, but still.
 "I'm not mad, just disappointed"

Slime Rancher 2 is an upcoming sequel to the popular game Slime Rancher. The game is a single-player, open-world game that revolves around exploring, managing a farm, and collecting different types of slimes. One of the most significant improvements in Slime Rancher 2 is the expanded world.
The game also introduces new types of slimes, which adds to the gameplay's variety. Additionally, now you can breed slimes to create new hybrid slimes with unique properties.

Alright, first off I'll talk about the main thingy of the game, the design choices and landscapes. They're beautiful, all of them are, they really outdid themselves with SL2's graphics. However, there are a few downsides to note:
Slime rancher 2's UI system.
It is, really bad, compared to the original. Another thing would be how they are adding steam deck compatability, which is really, REALLY nice, but the problem is even on the lowest graphics settings, I still get frame drops (and I have the most expensive steam deck), it's terrible. It's not from just having lots of slimes. It happens all the time. This is a nitpick but the colors are wayy too saturated, much unlike the original.
Another thing is the 'wilderness' theme. Second thing, awesome as it is to have many new slimes, basically all of them are animal related, which feels just.. bland compared to all the crazy slimes found throughout, which had very different mechanics that made them a bit hard to contain.
Like dervish, boom, mosaic, rad, Quantum. The new mechanics just feel.. off. I can't explain it. I doubt anyone would care about this review, especially devs because it's only an issue with me.

The open world thing is gone. You have to wait a while, then you're there. It does increase performance, I guess.. but.. why? And what happened to all the cool science stuff? The Drills and pumps now getting those resources are even more of a pain in the ass. It encourages exploring but not in the good way. I despise it. Especially Silky sand. And the teleporters are gone for all my knowledge, replaced with only 1 way teleporters. It helps but it feels lame. 

There's much more I wanna talk about but I don't have much time, I'll edit later.

If you liked Slime Rancher you'll love Slime Rancher 2, it is very much a sequel and it builds on the original, making the crafting system better, adding some new slimes, as well as intriguing story and lore. The visuals are even more stunning than the original, the score is just as great, and the design of the world encourages and rewards exploring. The jumping is a bit harder than the original, Bea seems to be floatier, but that seems to be intentional (maybe it has something to do with the mysteriousness of the island?). I also adore that you don't need to unlock a better treasure pod cracker, that was always frustrating in the original, finding one and not being able to unlock it.
Overall, a great game on it's own,  but also a great sequel that builds up on the original.

It is with a heavy heart that I write to tell you that I do not recommend this game. I absolutely loved Slime Rancher 1, and was eager to purchase the "sequel." I wanted to support the developer and encourage them to make more games like Slime Rancher. Unfortunately, Slime Rancher 2 is not at all what I was expecting. It is, rather than a sequel, simply a continuation of the story and feels more like DLC than a stand alone offering. The first game had progression and a story, this game does not. It punishes you for exploring, as you will have to work hard to get your ranch back in order when you return. There's no joy in finding treasure pods, as they turn out to be cosmetic items 95% of the time. The story line is barely there, and your friends only contact you to give you--you guessed it--cosmetic items. Don't get me wrong, I don't hate this game, but I prefer the first game 100x more. If you just want to catch and feed slimes, then you will love this game.  If you are looking for something with progression and you love to explore the world, then this is not the game for you. I know it is still in early access, but my hopes are not high for the future of this game. If you absolutely LOVED Slime Rancher 1, and have not yet bought Slime Rancher 2, then I recommend you wait on this one. Go back and play SR 1 for a while and see if the developers plan to make SR2 into a full fledged game.
