Slime Rancher 2 follows the same basic gameplay mechanics as the first game. Players take on the role of a rancher who must explore a colorful, alien world and collect various types of slimes. These slimes can be fed and cared for, and their produce can be sold for money, which can then be used to upgrade the ranch and purchase new equipment.

One of the biggest improvements in Slime Rancher 2 is the addition of multiplayer. Players can now team up with friends to explore the world together, share resources, and tackle challenges together. This adds a new layer of social gameplay that was not present in the first game.

The game also features new areas to explore, including a desert biome and a frozen tundra. These new areas introduce new types of slimes and challenges, as well as new obstacles to overcome.

In terms of graphics, Slime Rancher 2 looks very similar to the first game. However, the graphics have been updated to take advantage of newer hardware, resulting in smoother animations and more detailed environments.

Overall, Slime Rancher 2 appears to be a solid sequel that builds on the strengths of the first game. The addition of multiplayer and new areas to explore should provide plenty of new content for fans of the series. While some may feel that the game is a "cash grab" of the first game, it's important to remember that sequels often build on the mechanics and concepts of the original game. As such, Slime Rancher 2 may feel familiar to fans of the first game, but it also introduces new elements that make it a unique and enjoyable experience.

To be honest, I'm really struggling to give this game a positive review right now, I'm scoring it around 5.5/10.

The original game was pure perfection - any criticisms I have about it are total nitpicks. This game on the other hand, is headache / frustration inducing for me. I have vision problems, and the new graphical style of this game makes it very difficult for me to distinguish between objects / colors / movement / environment. I did not have this problem with the original game's graphical style.

This lack of ability to distinguish between objects / environment causes me extra grief since I'm constantly pixel-hunting for my desired targets, and also falling into the Slime Sea every fifteen minutes (only to lose the resources I took so long to find). (Note: I have tried tweaking the video settings such as brightness / gamma which made things even worse for me)

So far in EA this game is far-less-featured than the original, the pacing / tutorial are a bit haphazard, and if I hadn't played the first game I'd be completely lost (the original's pacing was so perfect it didn't need a tutorial). I'm also extremely disappointed with the unremarkable soundtrack, it's far less engaging than the first one. I understand these types of things are to be expected since it's still in EA, so I'm hoping some of these lacks will be fixed in upcoming updates.

I'm certainly in the minority with some of these disappointments (a few other people report photosensitivity and motion sickness issues with the new graphics), and I'm certain that some / most of these concerns will be fixed in time. I'm just hoping it happens before I give up trying to play the game, because I truly enjoy the Slime Rancher premise and gameplay, and I really want this to be my favorite game of 2023.

Really Not That Enjoyable at the Moment,
When I'm not pulling out my hair in frustration, being attacked by 20 tar, or falling through the floor into an endless abyss with no kill box, its pretty okay.
My main issues with the game at the moment are that nothing goes anywhere. I spent 2 hours hunting down and popping gordos and putting plorts in statues hoping to find some new slimes, or new content, and made absolutely no progress and found nothing. I know theres a cave with bats and crystal slimes or whatever in it somewhere but I for the life of me cant bare another hour searching for food and plorts trying to find it. Every single gordo and statue I found led too a dead end, a shortcut I couldn't even use because I needed to do something else on the outside of THE OTHER END, or just a kinda cool looking area with no use other than, well to look cool I guess. It's really hard to feel like you're making any sort of progress as unlike in the original game, every gordo you popped had a purpose, you knew where to go next because there was a stone door blocking the next area, and when you did find a new area it actually felt like A NEW AREA, everywhere looks the exact same, you could shuffle the map around and I wouldn't even notice. Speaking of the areas they are so meaninglessly large for what they are. I get lost so frequently from a lack of any distinguishing land marks what so ever. The only truly unique area is the one with the butterfly slimes where the steep cliffs and highland castle like envirement give it some personality. Even with such a large map area thet can fit a select few varieties of slimes into their own little areas I am constantly battling tar. I can walk into a brand new area and it will already be absolutely polluted with tar. This happens in pretty much every area of the game and I think that can be attributed to the phospher slimes that decided that they can spawn where ever they damn well please and destroy an entire ecosystem. It's an absolute shame I can't experience the soundtrack of this game because at least every 2 minutes the tar theme song decides to bud in on what I assume to be a pretty good soundtrack. I spent 90% of this current build of the game being lost and wandering aimlessly through a land of pure tar and slimes screaming in anguish. Although the game is in early access I don't really have high hopes for the future as I don't see any really new ideas over the original, this could have just been DLC at this point other than the addition of collecting items without machines or taps which I guess is a pretty nice quality of life change. This feels rushed, laggy, and like most content was hastily added to pad run time because it fells like everything is intentionally blocking my path in a way that it wasn't an obstacle, but a time investment. I really really hope this turns around because I know what this studio is capable of, and I surely hope its not Slime Rancher 1 + New Marketable Blobs. 4/10
edit: I know its early access theres gonna be unfinished areas just PLEASE tell me when the content is over so I can stop looking for it.

If you have ever dreamed of leaving to go live a secluded, tranquil life in the beauty of nature, or even dreamed of escaping life on earth and going to live alone on another planet, then this is the game for you. Slime Rancher 2 is a wonderful and relaxing escape from reality, with the perfect amount of skill and thought required to keep you focused, while winding you down. It is perfect to de-stress after a long day at work or school. The other characters rarely show up, but their presence helps to relieve any sense of loneliness, and builds such a strong feeling of care and community. Even though I received this game as a gift, I would have been willing to pay full price and more for it. It is very much worth the money.

As someone who had never played the original "Slime Rancher," I was excited to dive into the sequel, "Slime Rancher 2." From the moment I started playing, I was struck by just how cute and charming the game is. The brightly colored slimes and adorable creatures that populate the game world are simply irresistible, and I found myself completely absorbed in the game's whimsical atmosphere.

One of the things I love about "Slime Rancher 2" is how easy it is to lose track of time while playing. Before I knew it, hours had flown by as I explored the game's open world, caught and cared for different types of slimes, and searched for treasure. The game's relaxed pace and gentle difficulty curve make it the perfect game to play when you just want to unwind and escape for a while.

Despite my lack of experience with the original game, I found myself invested in the series and eager to learn more about the game's lore and characters. The game does a great job of gradually introducing you to its world and mechanics, so even if you're a newcomer like me, you'll quickly feel right at home in the game's quirky universe.

Overall, "Slime Rancher 2" is an absolute joy to play. Its cute and colorful aesthetic, relaxing gameplay, and addictive mechanics make it the perfect game to unwind with after a long day. Whether you're a fan of the original game or a newcomer like me, "Slime Rancher 2" is definitely worth checking out. I can't wait to see what other charming creatures and adventures the game has in store for me as I continue to play!

haven't explored much yet, but things that have catches  my attention are;
-would prefer if night sky was not blurry, I mean not completely sharp but stars I am looking at may become sharp. I believe that would look better. This way during night when I look at the sky I just can't shake off the feeling that the character is myopic.

-map overall can get a bit of more love. Map looks beautiful don't get me wrong, but the base, or teleport locations looking so good, I feel underwhelmed when in other sides of map. So I believe non-special locations of the map can get better, probably not to the level of special locations, but even half of it would look fabulous.

-idk if it can be worked out but loading screen for teleporting to different locations is kind of bothersome and is the only thing that got worse compared to first game. (though it may be a side-effect of the 2nd game being more  complex idk)

Things I liked;
-sun.  (watching sunset-sunrise is quite beautiful (SLIMES SHOULD ALSO WATCH THIS VIEW 100%) and sun's effects is not limited to this. I love the red hue it gives to all map during sunset-sunrise, even slimes should stop and adore this view

-oh nearly forgot musics, they are DAMN good

Things I would like in the game;

-moon's effect is kind of underwhelming compared to sun. Moon is kind of blurred atm so we cant see much detail but other than that maybe it could have a cycle. Sometimes a crimson moon giving night a crimson hue or a yellow moon, not necessarily having any effects. even only visual effects would be interesting.
-slimes sometimes should enjoy the scenery, since they like music why not (maybe smalls on top of largos and enjoying the sunset)
-more generous use of water in maps, but in a detailed way, rather than slightly covering the ground, maybe drizzling through rocks, little waterfalls here and there. Maybe a medium sized one dominating a corner. (edit: OK, I have seen a part of the map dominated by a waterfall, which is nice, but its textures is a bit muddy)
-while running vac takes too much space pov-wise, I would like to see game more even while running

Slime rancher 2 is practically a slime rancher 1 expansion pack with a new map and not much else to it. The game is still very new, being on patch 0.2.0 at the time that I'm writing the review but there is always the possibility of "seemingly big" but empty updates coming out all the way to version 1.0 of the game so just because its in early access, doesn't mean the game will improve over time.

The game has enough positive comments already because the first game was a massive success, but its good to keep in mind that the game has not changed at all. I will be going into more detail below.

I wish we had some earlier access to rare resource automation in the game. Most of my time spent playing was running around the very same locations collecting resources from the ground like deep brine or jelly stones just for 1 machine which doesn't feel rewarding enough anyway. 

If you want to progress at a moderate to fast rate, you'll most likely have a couple of spots dedicated to slimes and what I found was sometimes I would spend 10-15 mins purely collecting and selling plorts and feeding the slimes which honestly at first it might sound ok, but people underestimate the amount of time spent doing this in the long run. Sometimes I spend the entire in game day feeding slimes and collecting plorts or the auto plort collector fills up and all the plorts go to waste or the auto feeders run out of food.

In general, I think if you are patient enough and want to just kill some time, its quite good. It really is a reskinned version of slime rancher 1 though so bare that in mind.

what you can expect from the game, which may help you decide whether or not to get it:

Slime Rancher 2 is a sequel to the popular indie game Slime Rancher, developed and published by Monomi Park. The game is a first-person sandbox game where players explore and collect various types of slimes, which are adorable creatures that can be fed and kept as pets.

In Slime Rancher 2, players will once again assume the role of Beatrix LeBeau, a rancher who must explore new lands, collect new types of slimes, and build a ranch to care for them. The game promises to expand on the original Slime Rancher's mechanics, adding new slime types, new gadgets, and new challenges to overcome.

If you enjoyed the original Slime Rancher, or if you're a fan of cute and colorful games with light-hearted gameplay, then Slime Rancher 2 might be worth checking out. However, whether or not you should get it for free ultimately depends on your own personal preferences and circumstances.

I absolutely adore this game! I loved my time with the first game, and this is just more of that. whilst I do admit it is fairly similar to the first one (it is a sequal after all), I feel as if it changes up just enough to be worthy of the sequel title, like any good follow up. and yes, it is still in early access (current version being 0.2.0) it has just enough content of fun and polished quality to hook you, and get to exited for whats to come later down the road. especially considering that Monomi Park has all the experience that came along with building Slime Rancher from the ground up, you can diffidently see all that experience culminating here; the vast expanse and detail of the Rainbow Islands, all the new slimes and resources, and lore and character building with your interactions with the other ranchers and the mystery of the rancher that was there before leaving behind all the drones everywhere; hinting at what incident could've caused the strange, but beautiful  phenomenons occurring on Rainbow Island, and what on the Far, Far Range could be behind the giant cracked seal. All of this quality content has me eager for what is to come in the later updates, and goes to show the amount of effort, soul, and passion that has gone into this game so far. This right here is how Early Access games SHOULD be made.

As someone who LOVED Slime Rancher and followed development since 2015 I'm sincerely obsessed.
Since 2 is in early access, it's hard to recommend to people who haven't played the first game, but either way I find both to be worth playing. I love the art direction and improvements to the core gameplay loop has made the experience so much less janky.

My gripe with the first game was that the upgrade system, 7Zee and crafting felt at odds with eachother and it was difficult to get over that massive progression bump that is currency cost of expanding your ranch and upgrading your gear, THEN into resource cost for tech after having played long enough to afford the lab. Then steeper cost for 7Zee cosmetics, etc, etc. The challenge was rewarding, simply because access to automation and cute decor was actually quite fun and satisfying for the challenge. Especially since the automation gave push to perfect your ranch layout. But I wouldn't say it all felt naturally integrated.

With how Slime Rancher 2 is, currently, I think the balance HAS improved! Upgrades and crafting are now all united into one neat package, with the new upgrade and tech progression obstacle being finding the locked orbs. Which, depending on much you explore, has the potential to hinder your progress if you don't keep your eyes peeled and your nose to the ground, but it really isn't that bad. I'm also truly over the moon with how much better the movement system is integrated into exploration, although a lot can be traversed on foot, if you know how to use the jetpack you can use the environment to your advantage and get past a lot of the locked doors or find very well hidden treasures. Compared to the first game it has a lot more intended paths and intentionally reachable areas, rather than leading to what [i]felt[/i] like boundary breaking. Early on resource cost is a little rough but really it just pushes you to explore, and with how gorgeous the game is I have nothing to complain about! I'm pleased as punch with what we have and I'm looking forward to future with the potential this game has.

As a fan of the original "Slime Rancher", I was ecstatic to hear about the release of "Slime Rancher 2". And let me tell you, it did not disappoint.

The game takes everything that was great about the first installment - the adorable slimes, the immersive world-building, the addictive gameplay - and elevates it to a whole new level. The graphics are stunning, the new areas to explore are filled with secrets and surprises, and the addition of new slime types and ranching tools adds even more depth to the already impressive gameplay mechanics.

But what really stands out to me about "Slime Rancher 2" is the sense of joy and wonder that it brings. The world of the game is vibrant and colorful, and the slimes themselves are just downright cute. Every time I come across a new type of slime or discover a hidden area, I feel a sense of childlike wonder that is all too rare in adult life.

But beyond that, "Slime Rancher 2" is a game that brings people together. The community of players who love this game is truly a joy to be a part of. Whether it's sharing tips and tricks or just admiring each other's ranches, the sense of camaraderie among "Slime Rancher 2" players is truly heartwarming.

Playing "Slime Rancher 2" reminds me of the importance of finding joy in the little things, and of the power of community to bring people together. It's a game that will make you smile, challenge you, and leave you feeling a little bit better about the world. And for that, I highly recommend it.

The original Slime Rancher is one of the most peaceful and soothing games I've ever played, and this is very much an improvement. The slime science is more involved, and doesn't need me to sit around waiting for an RNG machine (although I do wish the spawn rates were a bit higher for the materials). My biggest issue with the previous game was how difficult it was to keep carnivorous slimes happy, since chickens always seemed to reproduce so slowly: in SR2, chickens spawn much quicker, to the point that I even have enough leftover Roostros to feed my Hunter slimes.

I do miss the drones though. Once your ranch gets big/efficient enough, it's difficult to find time to explore.

I played a lot of the first slime rancher. After 30 hours with this one, I think overall its pretty good. Nothing astounding, but a fun new entry, and while yeah, its very similar to the old, I sort of like that. Its another chance to build a ranch and create all kinds of largo, yippee, its more of a game that I wanted more of. And it feels like a more polished or smooth version of SR 1 in how the character you play as handles and the designs/graphics which is dope. I would recommend it but only if you really loved the first and want more of it. If you haven't played the first, get that not this. Oh, and the soundtrack is also just as good as in SR 1, knocked it out the park again with that.

However, there are some criticisms I have outside of recommending it. I do think the worlds seem to have a bit less flavour in places, like the starlight strand etc just don't quite feel as iconic to me as the indigo quarry or the ancient ruins or the glass desert, they are pretty to look at and still pretty good, just not as good. But, maybe thats me and it is minor. The new slimes themselves are really, really good, just A+ on them honestly. Very lovable, perfect.

The CPU usage is a bit insane, I had to put graphics on lowest setting and for the record my computer has ran sims 3 and another game in the background without lagging before so its not that I have a weak set up. I hope that is fixed/optimised and anyone with a weak computer should note it, maybe wait till developments further along.

The game is also very incomplete. That's not an issue on its own, I just really hope updates aren't too slow. Monomi Park seems like a trustworthy developer though and SR1 was always getting fun constant periodic updates so I'm not too worried. The biggest thing is just definitely not seeing more of the trend we're always seeing these days, incomplete games going early access then staying in that state for 5+ damn years. But again, I still recommend because while its always a risk, overall I trust this developer given track record.

That being said, one thing should be a priority that isn't in the game currently - drones. The actual ranching part of the game is just unplayable without them sadly. I mean sure, you can have stock food for the slimes and collect plorts yourself by hand, but you can only reasonably manage about a single or maybe two ranch expansions while still getting to explore enough. Otherwise you're constantly hurrying home and tediously removing plorts back and forth back and forth gets old real quick. The drones NEED to be a priority for the updates, I think really they should have launched with the base game honestly, but still, putting them in ASAP would certainly fix a lot I feel like. More exploration can come later when the tools to equip players to leave long enough are in place first!

As a final minor aside, I do honestly wish the conservatory was fully enclosed, or another one of the ranch expansions was, like with a fence or something. Probably just me but I longed for it in slime rancher 1 as well, just a way to have stuff free ranging if you so wish would be really neat. So good for chickens... half the time farming them is even more fun than the slimes itself hehe.

The new graphics and music are great, even though just a riff on the first game. Some revamped features are nice (no need for extractors all over the world, very hungry slimes leading to max plorts), but the grueling grind of having no drones or two way teleporters is intolerable.
Good game fr nga

Environment artists somehow outdid themselves and managed to make the game look even more gorgeous than before, which I didn't think was possible. The story is a lot more compelling than the last game as well, as I feel myself theory crafting in the mystery of rainbow isle. The new slimes are quite funny, and I like how they've expanded the background of them. Ringtails and Yolky slimes are a step in the right direction, they're creative and have a lot of personality.

This time exploration feels more rewarding, even if a bit daunting at times since it can be super easy to get lost in the areas, but after a bit I got the hang of landmarks and such. Having natural resources be an incentive as opposed to something you just plop an excavator down for was a good choice. Also kinda've glad I don't have to open more love letters from Casey every few minutes.

This game is heading in a great direction, and I'm eager to see it grow. I bought the switch copy of the first game for my little nephews, because deep down I think we all would like to retire to another planet to ranch happy blobs of our own in peace. My only ask is a multiplayer mode would be nice as the franchise continues to grow, so I can play with my friends and family.

Before you read this, BUY THIS MASTERPIECE.
Now the review.There are many amazing things about this game, from the beautiful graphics, to the magnificent frame-rate, and exquisite gameplay. There are plethora of plants and chickens to discover, and an expansive library of old and new slimes. It is very calming. I love the story at the moment, (0.2.0), and it is very interesting.

It's cute, playable with nice soundtracks. 

However as a fan from playing the original, I am disappointed... I recommend purchasing this and not the original if you're looking to play the game, but if you have the original... It's the same activity with a few new slimes.

The only thing I enjoyed about the game was the aesthetics of the new areas, but it's not enough to warrant this game as a "sequel".

I would have liked to have seen some new mechanics, like a bigger vacuum tank, a fishing game maybe - or even the multiplayer so many people requested in the original. Any other NEW activity other than vacuuming slimes in a new environment for money, to unlock more potential for money, for... What, exactly?

I loved playing this game. But I'm honestly not very impressed by it right now. I expected there to be a few more areas than the original slime rancher but granted the game is still in Early Access. I've run into a couple of glitches.. my favorite being as I've named "SLIME STACK" this happens when two or more slime's "stack" basically they get stuck together and can't unstuck themselves without being vac'd up. I was a bit disappointed when I found out how small the map IS. I'm hoping later in development it has a lot more areas. The slime's are just as adorable as the original slime rancher. But something I think ISN'T very similar to the original slime rancher, is the special slime's, I'm explicitly talking about the lucky slime. When I was playing through ALL of the original slime rancher I only encountered the lucky ONCE. But I managed to see this lucky slime 6 times while playing. So I'm not sure if they changed the rarity or not, but otherwise it's a bit hard to find and half the time you're just roaming around when it spawns. However I really did love this game and I hope to see more parts of development as it goes on.

I want to stress that I really do like this game, and I genuinely think when the game reaches 1.0 that it will be an amazing game, that said right now it has a couple problems.

Easily the biggest issue is the collectible treasure capsules on the map, which unless you want to spend hours trawling (and re-trawling when an update comes out) the map, your going to have to go on the internet and find a guide to show you where they are, if there was some kind of detector/gauge that showed you how close you are to an unopened capsule it would be immensely more fun.

Secondly, and this is actually a lot more minor, but slime ranching feels to be a really small part of the game currently, it feels currently the game is all about scouring the world for resources to get upgrades and decor, with very little slime ranching actually required.

Third is that all the convenience tech (teleporters, warp depot's, etc) takes a ton of grinding because they all require diamonds, so it just feels like a grindfest if you want to actually do stuff.

That said, for all 20 hours I have played the game I have had lots of fun, and I don't regret purchasing the game, but I'm not sure I would recommend this if you didn't know about the current shortcomings the game has.

Overall a pretty good game, but i have a few critiques and recommendations...
- The new resource system of mining them in world instead of using machines is fun but makes it very slow, if your gonna stick with this please either add markers to resource nodes like the Gordos or letting us make our own map markers for them.
- Make the other NPC's useful, overall i love Viktor but don't really care for the others because he is one of the only NPC's that gives you useful objects. While Ogden is giving me the recipe for a small bush Viktor gives me the recipe for a pink portal. not very fair to them right? I'm not saying to make them give portals as well but maybe things that make sense for them like bringing back Slime decals, drones (and maybe decals for them as well)
- The game lacks a driving force, Slime Rancher 1 had the Z Rewards giving you drive to make your farm more efficient and to explore to make your system even more optimized (and maybe find some gold or lucky slimes while your at it)
I do understand that the game is still in the early stages of its lifetime and has many things to come so if these are improved, they have done even better!

Alrighty... first addressing the elephant in the room: the COMICALLY poor performance. Graphics settings are irrelevant for the most part as well so just turn them all up (other than depth of field naturally) if you have at the minimum a 2060 Ti / 2070.

Other than that early-development problem basically everything has / had at some point, it's an excellently stylized game that's generally pretty relaxing- if a little frustrating at times with the lackluster map but that's more of a me problem as I have a history of having the navigational ability of a blind and deaf toddler.

Overall? Definitely a good buy, as long as you know what this actually entails. It's really chill, not a ton of mechanics to worry about, let alone sink tons of time mastering. Although there seems to be some early lore which has a lot of potential if Monomi decides to really develop it!

Also a minor nitpick, but a lot of animations run at a lower framerate than the rest of the game including the viewmodels. As I said- minor nitpick, but I figured I'd point it out.

This is an Early Access Review, and I'm going to be updating it as the game updates.

First release Review, Sept 27 2022:

It's actually surprising how much more SR2 is. When SR1 released in EA, it was less than half the size of what Monomi Park has released for this first release of SR2. The map is surprisingly large, with a plethora of nooks and crannies and a ton of underground tunnels to find and explore. The three islands we have access to are gorgeous, each with unique but vibrant color palettes. Gordos are now nearly guaranteed to hide a reward, whether that be lore, a treasure pod, a shortcut, or a teleporter. Extractors have been replaced with a simple add-on to the vac-pac, with nodes found throughout the world. Slime Science is now integrated from the very beginning, and upgrading Beatrix's kit is now a mix of money and science instead of an outright purchase from the 7ZeeCorp. Beatrix herself is also more "alive", with a few idle animations and different poses within the house depending on the time of day. There's way more conversing with the other Ranchers now, and though there aren't many lines of dialogue for repeat situations at the moment, the conversations about the lore and about what everyone is doing is a delight (still no eyes on Hobson, though!). There's a ton of hints to a ton of secrets and possibilities for upcoming updates that have me very excited alongside what we have now -- and all the upgrades that we have gotten already speak greatly to Monomi Park's growth over the development period of SR1. 

This is a FANTASTIC start to what is going to be a great game, and I'm happy to be supporting it and watching its development.

Update, Song of the Sabers, Feb 20, 2023

The first content update to Slime Rancher 2 is surprisingly huge! A new island, a glacier that's risen up from the Slime Sea thanks to the volcanic activity on Ember Island. Find the secret entrance and end up in a snowy little wonderland. 

Firstly, the snow mechanics are great. Beatrix sinks in, the slimes create furrows as they trudge through, and the snow sticks to them when they hop out. You can start snowball fights that will have slimes chucking tons of snow at each other, and you! The aurora plants are gorgeous, and the mechanic of the auroras becoming solid enough to walk on at night was a delightful thing to discover. The environment suggests that the glacier is broken off from the Ember Valley mainland, which is a nice touch that could have been ignored. It's a truly beautiful place with, again, its own unique feel. Monomi Park really knows how to design environments!

The saber slime returns in its pure form, with a cute roar mechanic that startles other slimes -- and the very first "utility slime", the yolky slime, who hangs out with the chickens and helps them reproduce faster. 

Story wise, there's more to see with the new drones, and even more speculations to be made.

All in all, this first update was great. It's a wonderful look into what SR2 is going to develop into. I think MP is doing a great job so far and I'm excited to see what the next update holds.

First "major" content update literally has less than 2hrs of content. It is being touted as a whole new biome and new thing and that, but its just recycled the sabers from SR1 into a "new" slime and added an egg variant of the fire/water slime. It feels like a seasonal/christmas update that they couldnt finish in time and are throwing it out as a content update instead. The initial early access content was already on the lower side of what we expect from a pre-release, but passable pending updates. Waiting 5 months for a 2hr play time update that doesnt even address the QoL issues is just meh.
Maybe I will change how I feel upon the next update, but right now I'm not thrilled on this.

Incredibly cute with fun gameplay, even in its early access form. Exploring is so much fun, and you pretty quickly get a jump jet-pack that opens up new pathways which allows you to explore even more. It's got a very satisfying combination of elements that remind me of Mario Sunshine and Luigi's Mansion in addition to farming games.

Some of the elements need refining or to be built out more. Looking forward to hopefully having more slime and food types, slime pen and bird coop upgrades, maybe slime incubators, and slime to item refinery tech, etc. Also I think it's a little silly that it costs currency to clear a building slot rather than refunding you. It would also be really nice if you could do a bird's eye view of your slime ranch to swap the contents of plots out - after unlocking more areas of my ranch I'd like to specialize each area but getting penalized for demolishing plots feels bad before your economy is set up.

I give it a solid 10/10.

Bottom line: Slime rancher now feels empty and unplayable without drones and new slimes, and the sequel feels more like a cash grab than a game the developers actually care about. 

Farm simulations/pet simulations, and other sandboxy sim games are among my favorite game genre. The first slime rancher is a very cute casual game that gained a lot of depth and things to do over the course of its development, including some MUCH NEEDED quality of life updates that made the game feel more of a joy to play than work to play. I was super excited about the idea of a new world for the devs to expand upon and make even better than the first game.

Slime rancher 2 feels like work to play. The barren and rough around the edges atmosphere of the original slime rancher is acceptable, it's the first game in the series as well as being a new dev team at the time. I have played and enjoyed many games in this genre that start sort of empty in early access, but I have NEVER played a SEQUEL of one of those games that feels just as empty as the first one. 

I see a lot of arguments about how "Well the first game started with almost no slimes, no drones, no achievements so why are you complaining??""  This isn't the first slime rancher game, this is the 2nd game. It should have no reason to launch as barren as the original title. "Developer mental health" Is not an excuse AFTER large portion of the audience already bought and played the game, if the devs aren't in a good condition to work on it or they didn't want to through the holidays, they should've been open with the audience about this BEFORE the game launched. 

I was super patient waiting for this first big update of 2023, and I'll admit I haven't played it yet. But after looking through the log it seems there's pretty much no quality of life for this update, just a new chunk of land and maybe 2 new slimes. 5 months is too long for an audience to wait in the dark for an unsatisfying first update. I'm going to give this new update a chance but I am already disappointed reading it over, as the game has been unplayable since launch without drones.

There is no reason to play slime rancher 2 as a new (or a veteran) player, I recommend the first slime rancher or any other related game in the genre.

Full day of playing so far and I'm loving it!
This was a game I've been waiting for for a long time. I'm so happy with it!

I will preface this next part by saying this game is early access, so I know there are going to be some minor issues. I don't really mind them! I know they are going to be fixed at some point so all is good :)

UPDATE: All the bugs i've mentioned below have been fixed :)

Some minor bugs I've come across:
-Same issue from the first game (exactly the same) where you can't pluck food from the plants. Which also makes it worse because this game you don't use drills, you use the vac to take the resources; so with this bug you aren't able to take any of them. Only fix for this is to close out of the game and relaunch. I've only ever noticed this issue if I've been playing for a long time (3+ hours). This is the one bug I hoped they would fix in the first one, and am sad to see it continues on this one.
-Small audio bugs throughout, but nothing too major. Only consistent one is I'm not able to hear plorts landing from the slimes anymore. It worked for about half an hour and then the sounds disappeared.

In all, not too bad, especially for a game in early access it runs great!

The recommended specs are misleading, and a 2060 super is more suited for 60+ fps gameplay. On RTX 3060, I could not reach target 120fps (steady 80-110) with or without external screen/mux switch. So bear in mind this is a graphically intense game better suited for a GPU paired with a multi-thread cpu. This is all based on medium-high settings.

For perspective, cyberpunk 2022 on ultra settings DLSS2 sported the game GPU temps as this game does for both my pc and gaming laptop (RTX 3060/3070Ti respectively) so laptop gamers beware.

If you're considering buying this because you love the original Slime Rancher, I'd advise against it. The game itself is good, and captures the feeling of the original game. However, in terms of content it's still far behind its predecessor. I'll probably change this review in future but for now it's a tough sell.

Right now there's about as many slimes as in the original game, however most are brought over, and only like 3-4 of them are actually new. The locations available right now are also lacking, only three unique ones in total and the starting area is pretty similar to that of the previous game.

From what I can see, one mechanic changed for the better. Gone are the time-consuming resource extractors where you had to wait for them to finish. Instead, you now simply vacuum up the resources yourself. Overall I would consider this a positive change, as I hated waiting for them. The gameplay is otherwise virtually identical to the previous game.

I've not finished, but I'm fairly late into the game, and barely any meaningful tech has been revealed to me. I've explored most of every biome, as well as corralled every slime in the game, and yet have not found any usable drones or two-way portals like in the previous Slime Rancher. Gameplay is thus a fair bit more tedious than in the previous game.

TL;DR, if you want a more complete experience, give it another year or so, and wait for more content updates.

So far, this game is incredible. I have yet to encounter a bug or glitch in my 4 hours of play (will try to update if that changes). The game feels like it's a fully fleshed out experience. There's already sprinkling of story lore throughout and I'm curious to see where it goes. The slimes are adorable and fun. The map actually marks discovered gordos or other important things you find which is a big help to not getting lost. Some of the lighting effects are a bit over the top (the refinery, refinery links, market, auto-feeders all let off a starry effect when you put things in them) and it can be a bit blinding especially with all the glowing plant effects, so I feel like that can be tweaked some. I have had some minor lag and texture loading delays, but nothing game breaking. The new resource gathering adds more player control rather than the original RNG of the extractors, so long as you know what to look for. Looking forward to more exploring and seeing where these incredible developers go with this amazing concept.

Edit: Still very few bugs or glitches. My biggest issue however is about controlling Bea. Her character seems very slippery/bouncy depending on what terrain you're travelling over. Running over a small rise can launch you five feet into the air. Trying to get to higher ledges can be difficult as some terrain bounces you off or is too slippery to land on (this may be by design to prevent breaking the environment). Really, all I think it needs is tighter movement and possibly the ability to toggle bloom lighting.

[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review [/h1]

[quote] PLEASE NOTE: This review is/was written when this game was in/is still in Early Access. Think twice before buying/playing this game [/quote]

Yet again, for a second time in a row, this is how Early Access is meant to be done!

Slime Rancher 2 is a game developed and published by Monomi Park and is the sequel to Slime Rancher

Slime Rancher 2 is a first-person management strategy game where you own a ranch full of adorable slimes, some are pink, some are blue, some are burning hot and some are very dangerous

The gameplay follows you, a rancher, where you have to build a pen where you stack slimes and you have to feed them and keep an eye on them from escaping whilst taking care of the ranch

Slime Rancher 2 is currently (at the time of this review) is in Early Access, but you really don't know that this game is in early access, because the game is big with a lot of content offered to you

The game is really good, however, the game can get repetitive after a while because you have to go back and forth with collecting slimes, food, water and so on, but overall, Slime Rancher is a very entertaining early access game!

I've been a large fan of Slime Rancher for a while, so needless to say I was rather excited when i learned about Slime Rancher 2.

So far, I've come across very few bugs, In fact none that i can remember off the top of my head besides one bug that wouldn't allow resources to be vacuumed up. That was an easy enough fix of restarting/reloading however.

The graphics and music are just what I expected from a game in the Slime Rancher franchise. Beautiful and absolutely relaxing. Its hard to describe the feeling from it aside from being deeply at ease. I find myself playing for long duration's at a time.

Moving onto the story line from what I've gathered thus far;
Bea has decided to continue her journey through a portal in slime rancher 1(or so it seems) and has continued to explore the planet. Many popular slime from the first game have reappeared joined by many wonderful new ones. 
Not much has been mentioned about what happened with Bea and Casey and casey seems to be entirely missing from this game. I won't say much more to prevent spoilers from the first game.
I think there could be some more work done to explain the transition from the first game to this one.

Its lacking a full story at the moment of course as while I am writting this, the game is still in development and incomplete.

Besides all of that, even at its current stage, it is a definite recommendation to play. You get the playtime currently of other rpg type games and theres a LOT for those who like to take completionist routes and unlock absolutely everything they can.


In conclusion, even in development, Slime Rancher 2 is a very well executed game. And if we're being honest, not a lot of players tend to play only for the story. Slime rancher is, in my opinion, the standard for relaxing games that are just an absolute delight to play (and not turn the in game music off in), and Slime Rancher 2 is definitely checking all my favorite things about the first Slime Rancher. I hope to see this franchise expand even more in the future


I would like to add, while yes its almost exactly like the first game, the story has been laid out a little, as well as some premonitions to future possibilities through in game mail. 
I would not recommend purchasing YET if you are only interested in story. Like some in the non recommendations have said, its beautiful and true to the franchise BUT not much happening story wise or new content wise yet! If you're solely looking for that, I recommend you wait to purchase until more is done, but keep in mind, Monomi isn't a big company. Acording to their website, theres only roughly 30 people working on the game <3 so things will go slow at first im sure! Just remember its a smaller company, and content won't come super fast (Also coming from someone currently in an alpha/beta test under NDA where there's been roughly 4 months between play sessions/content updates and each test only being for around a month)

I highly suggest you have a strong PC if you do manage to actually wanna play this game, when I say strong I mean super fucking strong. Have even the littlest outdated PC and your game goes to shit. 
First I am gonna talk about the little few positives this game has:
The menu revamp is amazing, the ability to disable tarrs and ferals is also a nice edition.
The new slimes, of course. A little lazy with design but still adorable.
The general map, the textures look beautiful and staring at them is like looking at a painting at a museum.
Now for the many negatives of the game:
The music is bland and repetitive, the thing that made the original slime rancher so great is how the atmosphere suited the music, for this it does not at all.
The fucking lighting, this is the main thing that makes this game so flawed. I have a moderate PC and I had to change the graphics to the lowest possible and yet still, the lighting is like looking at the damn Sun. If you go to hunt slimes, food, etc then you get completely blinded by the light above. If I wanted to get that effect then I would be staring at a flashlight which would honestly be a better experience. I also have several friends who got seizures because of this game's lighting.

And the gameplay while ranching the slimes has become super boring now because of the lights and the fucking intense lights. It is like I am playing the game at gun point whenever I try feeding my pink slime a carrot. It is stupid.
The bugs, the bugs... where do I start? First off, slimes spawning in your base, fucking stupid. I don't know if this is a feature of a bug, but I am listing it off anyways. The possibility of having a slime popping up in your base in very... unexpecting and seeing a Tarr pop up from fucking nowhere is unbelievable. I have lost so many slimes to this.
This could just be me, but whenever I try jumping on a rock, it flings me across the damn map and into the fucking ocean. Fix this.

The point is; if you want a good Slime Rancher experience without worrying about blind lights and Tarrs popping up from fucking nowhere in your base; Go play the original Slime Rancher, the graphics are generally worse but it is a fun and better experience then Slime Rancher 2.

I love games where you collect things, and so this game scratches that itch for me. Collect the slimes, get all the drones and pods, build all the gadgets, organize the base. Overall, I've been having a great time. Can't wait for the next update, which I believe should have a snowy area. It's honestly pretty addictive. 
Only downsides I have are that it's not super flexible in where you can build the gadgets, and the corals are pretty bare. But those don't really detract from the gameplay, and I still enjoy it immensely.
Slime Rancher is always worth it. <3

An extremely solid foundation with somewhat uncertain perspective. it's clear their first task was to move all the mechanics of the 1st game to the new engine, and so far it's mostly that - 1st game on a new map. Which is perfectly fine for an early access.

The graphics are beautiful. While I liked the visual distinction of SR1 biomes a bit more, overall SR2 looks miles better, and offers a lot of cool scenery to admire. Slimes look better than ever.

The exploration aspect of the new map is superb, with numerous hidden nooks to explore and secrets to find. However, the ranch is too big to comfortably manage, the portals in the world are extremely inconvenient, and system of manual portals isn't properly in the game yet. That makes repeated expeditions and managing of your slimes more of a chore than they should be.

There is also no money sink in the game, not yet at least, which quickly kills the need to manage your economy. Paired with annoying size of the new ranch, at some point it became optimal to just dump all my slimes in the ocean, saving myself from the need of hauling plorts over excruciating distances. This will somewhat get fixed once they reintroduce the drones, but so far they aren't in the game either.

New slimes are really great - Ringtails and Battys in particular introduce fun new mechanics to consider when making hybrids and planning the ranch. All of them also look great. Bunnycats? Bunnycats.

The food is also rebalanced. Chickens are finally a viable food source, arguably more viable than gardens even. This finally gives freedom to the hybridization system - if you want to make exploding cats, nothing is stopping you now.

The resource system is a massive change for the better. Instead of placing extractors and waiting for their production timers, you are now venturing back in the world to explore it more and gather the stuff you need. It reinforces the exploration aspect beautifully, though I think a few more resource nodes, especially in hidden areas, would make the whole deal even better.

The upgrade system, on the other hand, is a change for the worse. You aren't buying the upgrades anymore, you are crafting them from your resources, and SOME of those resources need to be gathered from specific treasure pods. Didn't find that one pod with final boot upgrade? Boy does it suck to be you. Better open the guide and kill the exploration thrill completely.

The story is in the same format as the first game - text logs found in the world. It's obviously unfinished yet - however, it offers an enticing intrigue to eventually uncover, and offers a nice spin on the logs themselves later in the game.

And that's about it. A very similar experience, fixing some issues of the original. A very solid foundation for an EA game, with some hiccups to eventually polish, and some incomplete parts. From this foundation, I hope devs add more unique mechanics to the future biomes, like with Glass desert, and new "modes" like they did with expansions of SR1. Then this game will truly outgrow its predecessor.
